40936840.review:
Niche is not a bad game. It just doesn't live up to its potential. 

The basic idea of adding genetic manipulation to survival is sound, since now one has a reason to mate specific critters. While that is as entertaining as expected when learning the game, once one is able ro establish the titular niche to survive and prosper in, simple math shows the hopelessness of the situation. Like in real life, when a population is too small, genetic doom is guaranteed. Inbreeding causes sickness, and that is great in theory, but is invariably watching your little tribe rot down the drain fun? 

Of course, the devs know that, too, so their solution is that from time to time a breedable stranger pops up out of thin air. Looks more like a workaround in absence of a solution, and it poses three integral problems. First, since the stranger is random, there is no guarantee that he or she has the genetic markers to provide healthy offsprings. Second, if the stranger has the necessary markers, now one has to deal with the fact that they have all the genetic defects one just took four generations to hopefully breed out of the tribe. In effect, one is almost guaranteed to lose all the genetic progress in the new offspring. This is a bad flaw, because there is a giant difference between grinding in order to accumulate microscopic advantages and rolling the same big stone up the same big hill time and again. Look at it this way. If a game makes you ask for grinding, it's not possible that the design comes together. Third, since the first two problems are necessary to cope with, what should be pure fun factor, like eye or fur color, is as wasted as the expansive list of purposeful defects. This cannot change with player experience or game progression, because the rhythm of four generations does not change with unlocking traits. 

As a result, when genetics are without consequence in longterm planning, breeding deteriorates to a mere here-and-now attempt to avoid defects. Or in other words, take "genetic" out of "genetic survival", and all you get is survival. What a shame..

Graphics. The latest iteration of graphics in the game is solid work. Even the purposefully ugly strangers  and their seemingly unavoidably ugly offsprings are totally cute. Where the game falls seriously short is marks. The first time I got infected by a swamp, surprise, surprise, I get it. However, why my ancestral knowledge tells me on one hand, that a hidden creature smells of danger, but on the other hand even my own experience leaves my senses completely impervious to environmental hazatds, is beyond me. It's a survival game? Exactly my point. Niche is nothing more than a survival game.

Also, is there a good explanation why I hover the mouse over a potential mate and the mating icon doesn't have a yellow or red ring for simple immunity incompatibility? Isn't it bad enough that the info ruins the gameplay? Do I really have to click around to get it?

Map design. While all by its lonesome the map design looks perfectly fine, it is completely ruined by how the game handles sickness. Ok, surprise, surprise, my tribe gets wiped out by the common cold. That happens exactly twice, the first and the last time. From now on, an infected toon is instantly isolated and in case of environmental causes, the infecting environment is off limits. In other words, once having lost a tribe to Ebola camouflaged as the common sniffles, all the random map design does for a player is creating variously large patches of dead space. That starts to sound worse, when you figure out, that three quarters of your island are dead space. Sure, I can just use that one quarter, but shouldn't be the very idea of a genetic game to develop reliable environmental adaptation, that doesn't evaporate every time I am forced by design to hump the most defect-riddled of the species? Is it really necessary to club the devs over the head with the hint that it may make perfect sense to give those annoying strangers dominant location-specific adaptations, since they actually LIVE in the location? I mean, given the fact that I cannot develop the adaptations myself?!? Apparently so. Despite wasting at least one of the two mutation choices on cold resistance on every creature I remember, I never once had an infected next to a healthy without passing on the death sentence. And while we are at it, having at one point an entire tribe of fishers, in nine hours on more than a dozen of maps I was not offered a single fish to catch. Not once. All that ability rewarded me with was three drowned. So, yeah, the map design is fantastic, just not for this game.

Tutorial. Yeah, I get it. Tutorials are for losers. Then again, in danger of being flamed by the usual trolls, wouldn't it make sense to make a tutorial, which isn't a waste of time? On which planet do I have to be born to need to actually click on a tile in order to comprehend how to move a toon? And enriched by this newly-found quantum leap of insight, now have to actually click on a bush, in order to comprehend food gathering? This game ails of two bad basic flaws the tutorial does buttkus to alleviate. First, mistake (avoidable, unavoidable, or most annoyingly, randomly punishing) means death (early or instant). Second, hidden contents is dead contents. About the first, I hope, I have used enough words by now in order not to have to repeat why it's a tragedy that the game insists on being nothing more than a mere survival game. As for the second, sure , I can find out by coincidence, that vicinity of packmates raises a newborn's comfort state. Then again, how much of a coincidence is necessary for this to happen? Let's see. Fact 1, my offsprings ignore my constant attempts of steeling them against the common cold. Fact 2, they frequently catch it upon birth in sunny grassland (invariably costing me the mother, who just transformed in the blink of an eye from my best chance of survival to yet anothrer dead end of my fruitless monkeying with genetics). Consequently, the game teaches me the hard way, never ever to have another packmate next to a birth nest. So how did I find out? One of those black thingies popped out of thin air into the middle of my well-manicured stomping grounds, making it necessary to throw everything at it but the kitchen's sink. Good news, I thwarted its evil master plan despite utlizing Critter Beam Technology (TM) - and pulling my tribe into an otherwise suicidal huddle, the baby got cozy. So, now that I learned something, let's be adventurous and actually apply the knowledge. Let's swarm a birth nest in preparation of comfort. Or not. Are you willing to bet the life of your tribe on the chance that the devs DIDN'T leave a rest probability of the little bugger catching a cold no matter what you do? I mean, given the fact that survival games aren't supposed to be fair and similar hogwash?

Yeah, I am aware of the fact that the lack of information is not worse than in pretty much every other indy title, but this game has changed from its beginnings. It is almost guaranteed that what little info one can find online is humbug. And sure it is possible to repeat the mistakes of the past and simply add a database. Which means counting on the fact that people know what question to ask AND counting on the fact that they are still reading after two screens of painful explanations, how to move a critter. Here's a better plan for the devs. Read The Sims' approach of concept teaching. Copy it, if you cannot do better. Unlock new concept tutorials via gameplay. Update outdated concept tutorials via in-game alert. If this is too much to ask, just do something, because virtually everything is better than having a "Help" button linked to a forum.

In summation, Niche works hard on being nothing more than a run-off-the-mill survival game. What a colossal waste of a neat concept.

> had 3 packs: the blind ones I degenerated by mistake picking berries, the sick ones cracking nuts and the strong healthy ones living at the edge of the jungle, scouting and killing for meat

40438072.review:
This was a game whose premise alone made me intrigued enough to want to play it. Weirdly I do not recall ever actually buying it; it would seem to have mysteriously appeared in my Steam library one day. A little while ago I noticed it has finally left Early Access so I thought it would be the perfect time to evolve myself a species of sapient underwater critters of some description. So without even a single look at the Store page or anything else about the game I leap into Niche, expecting a game of great freedom and great change over a long period of time.

Thus began the story of Adam, a fox-cat-thing carried off from their tribe by a giant bird as a toddler who grows up on an isolated island with no social contact of any kind, who literally ♥♥♥♥s the first ♥♥♥♥♥ he sees and sends all his children to drown in the ocean so he can research the "swim" gene, and then dies old age ten minutes later.

Is it my imagination or is something about that scenario pretty messed up?

This game is bad. If I had done literally any research on this game I would never have purchased it for myself. For a game about genetics there is not a lot of evolution going on here; you are always playing a subspecies of some kind of fox-cat-thing who can all interbreed with each other and every random creature they encounter. Rather than slow changes over time that can be controlled through careful breeding, there are a small handful of very specific genes. You cannot afford to breed carefully because everything in this universe wants to kill you and the lifespan of your foxcats is pathetic. The game has a story mode which doubles as a tutorial, but the story and the tutorial are both pathetic and forget to mention some extremely basic concepts. I understand the basics of genetics and selective breeding and as simplified and shallow as the system is I still could not figure out how it was supposed to work -- except insofar that genes can be unlocked by sending foxcats to die in stupid ways.

I would be less down on this game if it were turn-based. The game [i]looks[/i] turn-based at first glance, with every foxcat getting three actions per turn (less if they're not an adult). But everything else doesn't get a turn; instead they all get actions whenever you take one. So if your foxcat who has managed to mutate the Swim Body (yes, the entire form of your foxcat's body is determined by a single "body" gene) who you were hoping to breed with the Swim Tail foxcat happens to be attacked by a predator, they'll be dead by the time you move any tribesmates over to assist. This whole game is littered with bad design decisions. It doesn't just play like ♥♥♥♥, it even [i]looks[/i] like ♥♥♥♥.

I can't believe I'm saying this, but even Spore did evolution better.

40224683.review:
As someone that has studied "biololology" as well as actual genetics, I can tell you that this game is... well, let's just be frank here, it's unrealistic and overly simple. Does that make it a bad game? Hell no!

So what is Niche anyway? Niche is a game in which you manage a bunch of creatures. These creatures all have a a full set of "alleles". When they breed, they pass on one allele per gene. Depending on the alleles the child gets, they may have properties that neither parent has, simply because they are homozygote for some recessive allele or another. Or because they mutated.

So what's the goal? The goal is to use intelligent selection (which is different from natural selection) to breed your creatures in such a way that beneficial alleles for a given biome grow more common. For example, creatures that have mutated fins are better suited for biomes with lots of water, so you'll want to breed these creatures to attempt to amplify the allele. However, if a creature has fins in a desert, you'll typically want to avoid breeding with it. Beyond that, it's simply a game about surviving and getting at least a few of your creatures to the next island.

Is this game flawless? Nope, not at all. But does it need to be? I don't think so. It just needs to be good. On top of that, it's an excellent way to teach people the basics of heridity. Evolution, not so much. That has to do with the fact that this game allows the player to choose who breeds with who. Still, if you're interested in genetics, I highly recommend Niche.

39793633.review:
I grew up playing things like SimLife and Creatures, so I was pretty excited when I found out about Niche. Everything about this game screams something I would absolutely love and play endlessly, but the more I play it, the more I don't see this happening.

1. The game sorely needs a better UI that shows you your creatures' genes/sex/age/health at a glance. Currently, you have to click on each animal one by one, which becomes ridiculous as you breed more and more offspring to complete whatever genetic objectives you've set out for yourself. Every animal has a pair of immunity genes selected from a list of A through K, and having two of the same lettered gene gives an animal an incurable contagious sickness. This is to simulate the risks inherent to inbreeding, but also means that even unrelated animals can produce a sick child if you're not paying attention to their genes. When you're checking 15 or more adults every turn, on top of gathering food and navigating the map, not having at-a-glance information is frustrating.

2. If you have not reviewed this game on Steam, you will get an app-like popup on the menu every time you launch the game begging you to review the game. I'm sure the devs are very nice people, but they can fuck right off with that bullshit.

3. Maps are very feast or famine - you either land on an unforgivable island that is a struggle to survive on with constant sickness/parasites/predators or you get one that's almost boringly simple to colonize. There's no real in between, and a boring map never becomes challenging as time progresses.

4. The tutorial only explains so much. For example, you have limited control over gene mutations in your creatures, but the tutorial doesn't touch on this at all. The menu tells you that you can mutate two genes but gives you such little information that it's unclear as to whether you're selecting existing genes on the animal you would like to mutate into something else or whether you are selecting genes you would like to see mutated to in the animal's offspring.

TL, DR; it takes more than the 2 hours allowed for Steam returns for this game's problems to become entirely evident. I do wish I could get a refund. I'm a bit puzzled as to how this game is rated so positively, but I did really want to love this thing in the way I loved the games it was supposedly inspired by. There's no way I can recommend this to anyone.

39784944.review:
[b]EDIT[/b]: I'M NOT SAYING THIS IS A BAD GAME. I firmly believe that if you're interested in this game, you should try it, and at full price, even. I don't regret paying full price for it at all, despite my 'don't recommend' rating.

I really wish that I could recommend this game, but I don't think that I can right now. I've had the game since Early Access, and saw it promoted by some people as the 'better Spore'- but I've encountered some of the same issues as in Spore, though NOWHERE nearly as badly as Spore. The game crashes semi-frequently for me, and seems to fluctuate a lot between "wow, this is fun!" and "when will this part be over?" The sound has also given me a lot of issues with it crackling or sounding low-quality; however, the sound effects and music itself is really good.

It's sort of slow-paced and can be tedious, but I need to praise the art of the game (like nothing I've ever seen in another game, and weirdly adorable), the effort that the devs have put into it, and the genetics model. 

TL;DR-
You might love this game, but if you asked me for game recs, this wouldn't be on my list.

39738859.review:
Niche is without a doubt a challenging and surprisingly deep evolution simulator. If you like genetics, cute animals, and strategy games, this game is for you.

It takes a while to really get the hang of it. The gameplay is relatively simple turn-based strategy akin to games like Civilization, and for some people it might feel repetitive. But for me, the challenge and repetition is why I enjoy it; it's very meditative. This is definitely not a game where you can sit back and let things run themselves: Niche puts you in the role of selection, and the traits that pass on to the next generations are determined by your choices. You control each animal, and it's up to you to move them around and place them as you see fit. If you let any slip from your attention, it could prove fatal to the pack.

I would definitely recommend Niche to anyone who enjoys genetics and/or turn-based survival/strategy games. The graphics are lovely and charming, and the game runs very smoothly with almost no bugs.

To the developers, there are a few things I would love to see in future updates or expansions. Here are my suggestions:

- More goals or specific scenarios to complete. A 'scenario' mode that starts you off with certain conditions would be great, in addition to plain sandbox or story mode.
- A gallery of generations, where you can see all the animals you've bred over time. The family tree cuts off after a few generations which is really too bad. I would have liked to be able to compare my starting animals with the latest offspring.
- Natural disasters or random events that can change the landscape or wipe out your pack, perhaps even voluntarily chosen by the player
- 'Autopilot' mode

39619344.review:
I've been itching for a game like this for a long while, downloaded and played a bit back when it was rough (my first play save file is version 0.4.1) and it was exactly that - rough. But, I was hopeful. I opened it again this week because it still called to me despite its unrefined condition. Wow! It still is not nearly on par with any game you'd pay $40 for, but it looks and feels much better than I expected here in version 1.0.4! The camera is a bit of a pain if you don't like using keyboard shortcuts (can I get the screen to scroll when I move my mouse to that side of the screen?) but it's a beautiful and ten times less overwhelming middle ground between what Spore could have been, and Civilizations.

Pros: turn-by-turn lets you come and go and take as long as you want to strategize. You get a sense of fulfillment for curating and loving and protecting a little tribe through all the generations. It is fulfilling to the analytical mind: to those that thought about going for a degree in law, then decided you'd rather do something that didn't have real consequences so you browse /r/legaladvice and totally judge people who make bad decisions and tell them how they should fix it, all the while wiping your brow in relief that you're not in their sticky situation nor are legally culpable for any trouble they get in for listening to your half baked advice. Then, you load up steam and play this game, so happy you can have kids after kids without having to worry about everyone you ever meet telling you how you're parenting wrong and totally judging you, man.

Cons and suggestions to make even better: I personally felt a tad overwhelmed when trying to choose which of my pack I'd travel to the next island with each time. In part this was resolved when, through some trial and error that actually resulted in some fun inadvertent genetic bottlenecking, I figured out that the "pad" (going on memory, might be called something else) that everyone must be on is the flowery spots around the traveling rock, not JUST the spots directly next to that rock - and that water spots next to the rock don't count, either. Anyway, my suggestion would be that maybe in the tutorial you can only see a handful of the genetic traits (even if all of them are in play), so that when you're trying to decide whether to bring Romeo or Mercutio with you, you're not clicking back and fourth between their two genetic profiles for five minutes trying to decide if you value 6 fertility and a recessive swimming tail over a 5 fertility and an ability to crack nuts, and you really want to make sure that you're bringing the one with the most optimal traits for your preferences/plans/goals with you! 

If you're still reading this... you'll probably like the game. Just get it. I mean c'mon didn't you see that quirky trailer video that was not, like, the best thing ever but there's definitely something about it that's very charming, and who knows maybe it'll grow up to be that nerdy ugly duckling kid that turns out, just, the -epitome- of attractive, and humble to boot which none of the kids that were so hot and popular in high school will probably ever attain for the exact reason that they didn't go through that awkward phase (holy run on sentence, batman!): that's also how I'd describe this game. Thanks for reading.

39593010.review:
I really love this game. It's one I've wanted since I saw the very early stages of development. It's really reminicant of early genetic based PS1 games and PC games like Petz, only it's got more of a survival aspect. I enjoy trying to get my animals to have certain genes through breeding- but I had to look up explinations on the DNA user interfaces because the game itself never explains it in full. The tutorial is very lacking. For exampe when I first began I added two mutations to an animal thinking I could change them later, turns out once chosen you can't change them. Thats because the tutorial never explains that function at all, it's really just watered down to something like "you can give them different genetics through selective breeding" which is pretty vauge. It also doesn't tell you which genes are recessive or dominant, just which genes are currently active and which are not active (active is highlighted and dim is not- not an indicator of ressive or dom as far as I can tell). 

My other main gripe is that I started the story mode- and have yet to see any actual story since begining. You see the cutscene when it starts... and that's it. I've been playing 6 hours, and nothing else interesting has happened. A bird randomly showed up without warning and ate one of my kids a few hours in and I got an achivement "Adam's Curse," which I GUESS is kinda story? But not very much. To be clear, I am not on the first island, I've travelled at least 6-7 times now and still nothing really new. Grasslands and swamps. I haven't even seen a hot or cold biome yet, so I'm assuming those are rare?

The game is fun as a basic survival/strategy game and if you're like me and adore genetic based games. The genetic system is proably one of my fav features, even if I don't fully understand it. Seeing all the outcomes of selective breeding is really fun. If you don't like repeatativeness, be warned. There are bits and pieces to keep it fresh, but you will be doing a lot of the same thing over and over again.

I'm going to keep playing cause 6 hours in and I still personally find it entertaining, but I can't stress enough how much I hope there is some actual story soon. I'll be really disappointed in this game if "story mode" is just the cutscene at the beginning and reuniting with the family at the end with nothing in the middle.

1.引导内容太少，游戏里许多东西要玩家自己去探索，如果不是去网上搜资料，很多功能可能玩20个小时都不会发现
2.说明文本太简单，起不到指引的做用，比如 一个爪子，他就写一个爪子，不知道是为了保证这个生物一定会有爪子还是保证他有基本的挖掘攻击等功能
3.生物多了以后操作很麻烦，当你有30-40只动物的时候，大约有15只是固定收集食物的，那这个问题就来了，为了保证食物平衡，每个回合都 要有30次-40次的收集食物操作，说实话，严重影响体验。希望一些重复操作可以用自动收集来代替
4.游戏界面可获取信息太少，一个动物的所有信息，需要切4个界面才能看全，这个就让人不太能理解了，我想培养一个好生物出来 ，要把可能父母切个遍，至少也要切8个界面，还没有快捷键，生物少的时候还行，生物多了，尤其是有两个或以上宗族的时候，那真的是很痛苦。
5.生物寿命短，这个可能是为了让玩家体验培养的乐趣，但说真的，太短了，就活20多天，本来起个名字要区分一下，活没几天就死了，名字还不能继承，就很烦。

从游戏内容来讲，我应该玩了1/3左右，剩下那些也想体验，但是耐性这个东西，很容易被磨没的。
期待以后更新更多内容吧，文字说明详细一些，我会考虑改推荐的。

39050289.review:
I have stumbled upon on Niche about 3 months ago, and I must say, I immediatly fell in love with it. The graphic style of it is very unique and colorful, and it gives you a vibe of happy and cheerful game, which I think fits this very well. But, of course you can change that. You can make a tribe full of gothic-like creatures, that live in the swamp. You can make a tribe where everyone lives in the water. You can basically do anything. You can shape your story however you like.
These are just a few examples of how many options there are.
There is no goal in this game, only to survive. You can do many challenges in this game, which makes it even more interesting. Talking about challenges, the game is not going to be easy all way.  Sometimes it can get hard trying to unlock the genes, to make a specific tribe, but thats part of th fun! There are also rouge males, predators, nicheling-eating plant, you need to keep an eye on, and many more obstacles. And then of course there are genes. Probably the most important part of all. 
Now, I have a few cons about this game. First, sometimes it can get repetetive. When you have raised species you wanted, and they are healthy, there is not much to do then. I tried unlocking all genes, exploring, raising a new species....it still makes it broing after time.
Second, when a female is pregnant, you can put her onto a nest, and she will give birth over night, just like that. When she gives birth, she can just go away from the baby and breed again or do something else. I know not many games are realistic, but when I first played the full release version, I hoped they would make the mom stay with her baby and maybe somehow feed it with milk, as a maternity instinct to protect it, and care for it.
Third and final con is that you cant see the whole family tree. When you move to the next island, there are only the creatures that you brought to the next island, and their parents/kids. It is then very hard to remember who had who, if he 
is related to her, especially for story-tellers like me.
Thats all I have to say. Overall, the game is beatyfuly made, and it lags very rarely, I dont see any bugs at all.
I sure recommend you to try it you. :)

38962355.review:
I love this game. 

However, many others wouldn't.

If you don't want to read the whole thing, here's a quick summary:

PROS
Little to no bugs, doesn't crash
Colorful, cute graphics and characters
Wide selection of genes to unlock and breed for
Wide variety of islands to explore, each containing their own secrets (seriously, the savannah catches on fire)
Many ways to challenge yourself

CONS
Tutorial is very lacking (though it's getting an update to rework it, so this might change)
Repetitive and bland at times
Hard to pick up without outside guides since the game doesn't explain much

I'll go over some of the basics of Niche. First off, as far as I've seen, there are almost no bugs and the game has never crashed for me. It's also very rarely laggy.
The graphics are clean, simple, and colorful, which is a plus, but sometimes they're too simple. Like another review I read, I believe adding small animations to the nichelings would be endearing, whether they're idle animations or even just paw movements when actions are done.
You start off with five empty save slots that you can create worlds in. There are two modes, Story and Sandbox, with Story mode having more of a preset endgame goal and Sandbox being for more experienced players to make their own goals, while they can choose their own islands.
If you've never played before, definitely start off in story because sandbox doesn't have a tutorial. While Story does have one, it's rather lacking and I'd recommend reading the community guides to help you out because the game has many unexplained aspects. The tutorial is getting an update, though.
You start off with 1/2 nichelings, depending on your mode. In Story, the main goal they give you is to reach the main character (Adam)'s home island and meet the other nichelings that live there, his family. Once again, for a better explanatioin look for a community guide. In Sandbox people create their own goals- there are many challenges you can make and give yourself, along with trying to obtain certain genes. Genes are one of the defining factors of Niche, with a wide selection that can give you completely different nichelings if you carry the right genetics. However, the genes and breeding are not explained very well so if you don't understand it, find a community guide.
The game itself is not packed with action or tension. There is combat against predators, but it's mostly swiping against the enemy, breeding for higher strength, and then swiping again. Some are way tougher than others, but the combat process is the same. Don't buy the game if you're expecting a fast-paced combat simulator.
It can also be rather bland at times, and repetitive, but there are many biomes and islands to explore and every new world is different.
However, the game has high potential for storytelling, and is like it states: a genetics survival game. You collect food, breed, and fight to survive, all the while trying to breed out bad genes and keep the good, helpful genes. There are a wide  variety of nichelings possible, and you can tell stories and give each nicheling their own character and personality. Want your leader to be strict, cruel, and harsh? You can have them banish the rogue children, or even feed them to the birds. Want an ultimate fighter with genes of a predator? Go ahead, but it'll take quite some time. It all pays off when you see that 12 strength, though (haha). Over half the genes are locked when you start off, but there are different ways to unlock them all and different islands you have to explore. There's a whole system of dominant/recessive and each gene benefits/harms your nicheling's chance of survival.
There are also many things that can harm your tribe- freezing, overheating, starvation, predators, and leeches are only a few. A part of the game is based on luck, since you could begin the game and run into a predator immediately, while others might find a whole bunch of healthy wanderers with great genes. You can't always be sure what's going to happen, especially when moving from island to island, wihch is another reason I love the game.
The cores and basics of the game are very solid, however there are many small things that could be added that would improve a player's experience. The in-game messages don't tell you much- for example, some genes simply say "Travel to new islands" to unlock them, which can be confusing.  

Hope the review explained enough for you to form a basic opinion on the game, but you'll understand it much better if you play it! Overall, it's a definite recommend, and you should get the game if it's within your price range, and you think you'd be interested in it.

38949423.review:
Not a bad game but it has a little less to offer than a 18 dollar price tag would suggest. I was not suprised to learn it was Kickstarted and made by a small team. I think they did well with their means.

The gameplay feels more like a board game than a simulation, with action points, hex-grid movement, and sightlines. Reproduction is key as the longest lived animal only lasts 2 dozen turns, which naturally introduces the dilemma of who do you breed? Which traits do you want? Which don’t you want? Do you want to risk the chance of inbreeding to propagate a good trait? Do you cast out those with bad traits you want to weed out? The system is natural and intuitive and is even better that it well mimics the natural processes it’s based on. 

Overall however, I feel this game could have used more effort put into it, not that I’m saying that that they didn’t put in enough. What is there is clearly put into the most important areas. The creatures are adorable and diverse, the genetics system is extensive and well designed. Those two things are the most important parts of the game and are well done. 

My biggest problems with the game are the simplistic graphics, the lack of animations, and the clunky user interface. 

I really expected more based upon the screen shots and the price tag but most of the environments felt bland, uniform, and tame from a graphical perspective. I got used to it but it was still a bit jarring. I’m not expecting physics and total realism, but a little more detail would have gone a long way towards making me feel like I’m exploring a wild and uncharted archipelago. 

The animals lack nearly all animation which makes them feel more like board game pieces than animals, which is a real missed opportunity to further endear these cute animals to the player.

The interface was another missed opportunity which would truly benefit from some extra spit and polish. I found myself misclicking during actions in attempt to unselect or select different creatures but it wasn’t terrible. The notifications were not as helpful as they could be and should have taken a page from other games. Mousing over them should display their text and each’s text should have (where appropriate) the name of the creature, cause of death, damage values, etc, instead of showing a generic ‘a creature has died’ message. Clicking it should center on the area of interest and/or highlight the area/individual instead of opening a pop-up which must then be clicked.

Also with the interface, the thing I wanted the most was help managing my creatures’ genetics. While I like how the family tree graph and gene layout is displayed I want more. It is easy to forget who is related to who, who has too similar genes, which pups I wanted to ‘betroth’, which animals have and haven’t been bread. Since they have such short life spans it’s a lot of work to keep everything organized. I’d kill to be able to look and see [b]“Oh this new guy I can recruit has unique immunity genes which would be great for our genetic diversity! Get him!”[/b] or [b]“Ugh, this guy has the same stuff as everyone else and no cool traits, shoo!”[/b] without having to write down his letters and compare them against all the other animals I have individually. Being able to tell who was male and female at a glance would have made mating a lot easier. At the very least a risk indicator of inbreeding chance before mating would help. If there is one aspect of the game to improve (in my opinion) it would be this. It would make things so much more enjoyable.

All that being said while I hope they update the game to make it better I would totally buy a $10 or more expansion that remedies these issues. This game has all it’s core mechanics nailed down and would really shine with more TLC with improvements and elaborations.

38818046.review:
In diesem Fall wünschte ich, man könne mehr kriterien angeben, als nur Empfehlung oder keine Empfehlung, denn dieses Spiel macht mich zwiegespalten.
Eigentlich war es ganz unten auf meiner WUnschliste, aber mein Bruder meinte es passe total zu mir und hat es mir zu Weihnachten geschenkt.

Das Spiel ist wirklich niedlich, die Tierchen sind interessant, es ist abwechslungsreich und spannend und der Stil passt wirklich zu mir. Allerdings gibt es eine Menge, das ich daran zu bemängeln habe, weshalb ich lieber Punkte vergeben hätte, als eine klare Empfehlung.

Die Kritikpunkte beziehen sich vor Allem auf die mangelnden Einstellungsmöglichkeiten. Man kann entweder Story oder Sandbox spielen, wobei man sich bei Sandbox offenbar nur aussuchen kann auf welcher Insel man startet. Es gibt also 2 grundlegende Spielmodi: Einfach (Story) und Schwer (Sandbox).
Die Story ist nur deshalb einfacher, weil das Startpaar durchaus schon ein paar nütliche Fähigkeiten hat, die einen eine Weile überleben lassen, wobei Evas Gene vollkommen willkürlich sind und man, wenn sie einem nicht gefallen, im Grunde noch mal anfangen kann, bis man eine Eva mit guten Genen bekommt.

Was ich schade finde ist, dass man sich bei der Sandbox nicht auch die Gene des Startpaares aussuchen kann.
Ich vermisse irgendwie auch einen gesamt Stammbaum, nicht nur von aktuell "enthaltenen" Tieren oder einer Anzeige wie lange man denn jetzt schon überlebt hat.
Auch der Tageswechsel überstürzt leider völlig. Ich kann mir vorstellen, dass es längere Spieler nerven würde, aber ich fände ein Popup ob man den Tag denn wirklich beenden möchte wahnsinnig hilfreich, erst recht wenn noch Tierchen Züge übrig haben. Leider schon mehr als ein mal ist es mir passiert, dass ich versehentlich auf "Tag beenden" geklickt habe statt die Sicht umzustellen, was ich eigentlich vor hatte. Bisher hatte ich lediglich Glück, dass ich dann noch immer genug Futter hatte. Auch hab ich wegen eines unfreiwilligen Fingerzuckens schon mal einen Doppelklick auf den "Tag beenden" gemacht und es sind tatsächlich 2 Tage umgegangen!! Vielleicht bin ich beim Klicken manchmal etwas hastig, denn eigentlich hat man keine Eile, aber nerven tut es mich schon.
Man kann zwar die Kamera wie gewünscht bewegen, aber manchmal verstecken sich einzelne Jungtiere dann doch hinter irgendwelchen Hügeln oder man lässt sie versehentlich ins Wasser laufen, weil man nicht richtig gesehen hat auf welches Feld sich die Pfotenabdrücke bezogen haben.

Allgemein vermisse ich vor Allem eine "Rückgängig" funktion. Nicht nur wegen der versehentlich verschwendeten Tage, auch laufen sich manchmal auf die falschen Felder, weil da so viel los ist, dass man die falschen Tatzen sieht, oder andere Buttens im Weg sind. So haben auch schon manche Weobchen dummerweise das Nest auf dem sie saßen wieder abgebaut anstatt das Gras des nachberfeldes zu mähen.

Auch, dass man nicht zwischenspeichern oder einen Spielstand kopieren kann, finde ich äußerst schade. Wenn man durch ne Menge Pech eine tolle Kolonie in den Sand gesetzt hat, ist das einfach sehr frustrierend. Auch zu sehen wie sich eine tolle Kolonie in einem kopierten Spielstand verschiedene Richtungen entwickeln kann, wäre toll zu entdecken gewesen.

Klar, das sind alles Dinge, die das Spiel gewissermaßen "einfacher" machen würden, aber Ich finde das Spiel in der Hinsicht einfach etwas unausgereift. Es gibt eine Menge, dass man an Funktionen besser machen könnte ohne an der Spielmechanik irgendwas zu ändern, nur um dem Spieler selbst mehr Entscheidung zu lassen, wie schwer man es haben möchte. So hätten auch eher Menschen mit einem sehr niedrigen Frustrationslevel (wie ich) mehr Spaß an den Spiel.

Fazit: Ich gebe eine Spielempfehlung, weil es mir durchaus bisher spaß gemacht habe, auch wenn ich sehr vieles vermisse, was an Einstellungen (nicht an der Spielmechanik) hätte besser gemacht werden können.
Die Tiere sind niedlich und das Züchten mit Rücksicht auf die Gene ist sehr interessant, aber ich würde mir wirklich wünschen, dass es mehr Funktionen gibt.

38797803.review: Wonderful! Although I'm not great at the game yet, each of the nichelings is incredibly unique, and the concept is very creative! It's very cheap for what it is as well. I highly recommend this!

38797477.review:
I discovered this game thanks to Jessimew, and I loved it since the beginning. I played around version 0.1.5, and the game has improved in some ways since then -- but it also has gotten a LOT more complicated. I'm going to attempt to tackle each issue with thought and give credit where it is due. Thank you for taking the time to read this.

First thing's first, back in 0.1.5, for those who did not play back then, I'll simplify it for you. Back in the day, each action consumed your "berries" or "food source." It was extremely tedious work, and I'm very glad that the development team found a way around this -- so now your food source is diminished by how many pack members you have each day that passes. Not only is this more logical when it comes to how often food is consumed by animals in real life, it makes surviving a bit more enjoyable when it comes to collecting food.

However, the new user interface ( UI ) has gotten much more complex. Where you could once easily check your nichelings dominant and recessive genes, it has now become an entangled mess. While I get why they wanted to make it look more appealing with a DNA strand design, it is very confusing to the eye. I liked having one column for dominant genes, and yet another for recessive. For new players, some may be unable to identify what is even recessive, and what is dominant when it comes to their nichelings genetics.

As for the new genes, I am very excited and in-love with all of them. I think maybe there should be a help guide to explain a bit more in-depth about the genes, as it is difficult to look at a giant board of them. When chosing what genetics you'd like to have in place for breeding, it is very confusing to look at. They should atleast be divided into seperate locations such as -- mutations for ears, mutations for color, mutations for the body shape, etc. etc.

Evenstill, there are lots more that the game could improve on -- but those were the main topics. I really do love this game with its adorable design, unique play-style, and much more. I'm glad that they've tried to make genetics into a fun topic to enjoy and indulge in, but until some of these changes are made -- I, personally, am still going to struggle with liking the game as a whole.

Thanks yet again for reading! ~Shalefoot

38596130.review:
Do I think this game is fun?
Yes, I do

But, would you?
This game is long and drawn out, at least in my opinion. It's slow paced sometimes and may be tedious, but its a good game.
The goal is to survive in an unforgiving wilderness, with only your wits and whatever Nichelings you find, but how?
In Niche, you can mold and bend your little creature's genetic material to an extent, though it doesn't give you complete freedom. Each Nicheling is different in one way or another, whether its physical capability or appearance.
Breeding combines the genetics of the parents, sometimes you may just end up with a clone of a parent.
Over a hundreds of different combinations allows for breeding to be a wildcard. With certain match ups, you could breed complete trash, or a force to reckon with.
You also have to worry about feeding this niche of creatures. Each consumes 1 food per day, which is not as bad as back in the earlier versions. Foods sources you can use are berry bushes, trees (nuts,) fish, AI critters that can stumble upon your pack, and more!

With careful managing, your niche can thrive. Just watch out for those Rogue Males, who'll seek any females of your pack and mate with them. As you progress, you may start getting bored of your island, or you've cleared it off. When you do, you can send 7-8 Nichelings to the next island, who knows where you'll end up. Theres the forbidding jungle, where apes of different senses can wipe out the weakest of the pack. Large, predatory carnivores that are more of a nuisance than a real predator sometimes. Then theres the mountains, an unwelcoming place with dangerous creatures, and not much food to go with it too.

Niche is visually appealing, with nice graphics to go along with the great gameplay. The music is lovely too, and I have no complaints here.

Overral, Niche can be difficult, or easy, depending on how you'd like to play it. Its aesthetically pleasing and very fun if you have the patience. If you don't like games where you play god, I wouldn't suggest this.

かわいい+遺伝+サバイバル なヘクス/ターン制ストラテジー。
なんといってもキャラクター(Nicheling/ニーシュリングという生き物だそうです)がかわいいですね。
ニーシュリングを選択したときの鳴き声もかわいいし、カーソルを動かすと目で追ってくれるのもすごくいいです。

遺伝を売りにしているゲームですが、かなり単純化されている上に新しくなったチュートリアル(12/17現在ではpreview branchを選択しなければならないが)で基本的な説明はされるので取っつきやすく仕上がっています。
ニーシュリングの見た目と能力は21対の遺伝子の組み合わせで表現されていていつでも見れるため、親から子へどのように遺伝するかの予測は簡単にできます。個人的には育成・繁殖系のゲームによくある、隠されたランダム要素にわずらわされることが少ないのが良いと思います。

サバイバル/ストラテジー部分はヘクス・ターン制・ステージ制になっていて、ステージ=島から島へと移住しつつ餓死しないように食料を集め、子孫をつくり、少しずつ能力・見た目を変化させながら進んでいくことになります。特に明確な勝利条件はなく、Story Modeだと一応目指すべき場所があるものの無視してもよいので、交配を重ねて能力・見た目を好きなように変化させつつ生き残り続けることが基本的な目的となると思います。ゲームの方から目標を設定してはくれないので、自分で「特定の見た目だけでそろえる」「ユニット数は６まで」などの条件を設定して遊ぶのが好きでないと飽きてしまう可能性が高いと思います。

・良いところ
ニーシュリングがかわいい
グラフィックがきれい
雰囲気はあるが、主張しすぎないBGM
シンプル
論理的でわかりやすい遺伝システム
自由度が高い
頻繁にアップデートされている

・欠点
似たような画面が続きやや単調
明確な目標が提示されない
マニュアルセーブ不可オートセーブのみ
日本語に対応していない

お値段は安くはありませんが、ニーシュリングのデザインが好みで、いろいろなニーシュリングを育てて遊びたいと思えるなら買って損はないです。おすすめします。

38324705.review:
Early Access Review after many updates:

1:Genre(2/5)
Generally i am not a big fan of turn-based-exploration games, and this one even makes it worse. If you have a large clan, pack , tribe or whatever, you spend most of your turn collecting food. The exploration isn't too exciting either as you come across the same types of landscape all the time.

2:Gameplay(2/5)
As mentioned  in the Genre-Section, this game consists mostly of collecting food. And because you spend most of the time doing that, you may lose track of your animals and what you wanted to do with them. 
The most fun part is of course the procreation and trying to create a healthy and good looking pack , but in order to do so, you have to create very many other animals, who then just stand in the way or use up all your foodsupplies. And maybe I'm just unlucky, but i always have the problem that i have 10 females and 1 male in a pack, or the other way around, and you are scared all the time of your last male or female dying.
They have tried to improve the information-section on genes and inheritance, but i think something could be done to make finding good pairings more simple, i.e. being able to filter the family tree.
A point that looks really interesting when reading the game description are the biomes, but there is not a very strong connection yet between biomes and animals and how a different space changes the appearance of the animals.

3:Story(1/5)
Recently they have added a "Storymode" which is a very missleading name, because all it is so far is an inadequate tutorial and a "mission" given at the beginning of the game.

4:Playtime(3/5)
It is possible to play this game for 20+ hours maybe, which is an ok time for the price, but while and after playing it, i would consider it more like a time-wasting activity.

5:Graphics&Sound (3/5)
Nothing special or memorable concerning sound, but the graphics in general are quite nice and fitting for the game, and it is possible to make pretty nice creatures, the world around could use some work on the uniqueness-factor.

Overall: (2,2/5)
I am sorry that I don't know what is missing in the game, but something is missing to make it truly fun.

What I have to add to the review, though is : I really love the detail they put into the DNA and how the different genes are passed on. That is a nice treat for people who like biology and being able to use what they have learned in school.

38127077.review:
Ah, Niche. This is an odd one - I've got a bit of a love/hate relationship with this game, but ultimately I keep coming back to it. Why? Well, to explain that, I've gotta tell you a little story.

It starts out innocent enough. You've got your little fledgling tribe living happily on a paradise island: plenty of food, minimal predators, temperate climate. You could keep your tribe there forever and never have a problem.

But the young ones start getting restless. They see other islands on the horizon, and are itching to explore them.

So a few of them just set off one day. They end up somewhere new, with new dangers and new challenges. Odds are, they're not prepared for it. Food supplies run low. The predators close in. Some of your tribe die, and the others are weak and desperate.

There's food on this island, but it's hard to get; the plants poison you or injure you, and the prey fights back.

The old pack members make a sacrifice to preserve the young. They take a one-way journey to hunt or gather, and the rest of your pack survives with a few less mouths to feed.

It becomes a tradition. Once they're old and weak, they go off to find food and die in the process.

Then the imperfect and ugly offspring, those not fit to breed, are subjected to the same fate. It's all for the good of the pack, after all.

It's a ritual. It's an honour.

And just like that, your innocent little pack has turned into a clan of ruthless death cultists... and you never even saw it happening until it was too late.

So, yes, the criticisms of this game are valid. If you play it just as a strategy game, after a while it starts to feel directionless, unrewarding and ultimately pointless. There's no solid goal or checklist to tick off. Survival is easy enough for the most part and there's no real motive to explore except for an additional challenge, but that's circular logic. You want to survive, so you move to a harder island? Eh... what?

But the fun starts when - instead of seeing it as a strategy game with you moving a few dumb pawns around to accomplish... well, nothing much - you start seeing it as a story. Because that's the strength of this game, and it's a damn strong one.

Conclusion, then: if you're just in it for the strategy, give this a pass for now. But if you're in it for the animals, or the genetics, or the stories your pack will tell you, then buy this game. I guarantee you won't regret it.

37958490.review:
It feels like this game was made specifically for me. I grew up playing Petz (the PC ones, not the crappy 3ds version that came out later) and was part of the vibrant online community for the breeding, showing, and modding scene. I loved a horse racing game I had on the PS2 because of the breeding mechanics. Modern games have largely left breeding that even pretended to resemble to real life genetics behind. So, for years, I've been keeping an eye out for some type of pet/horse/whatever simulator that goes more in depth. 

And BOY, does Niche go in-depth! -At least comparatively. There isn't dominant epistasis or redundancy or really any dihybrid gene interactions as far as I can tell, but it does have the basic mendelian genetics of dominance/recessive, incomplete dominance, and codominance thing going on which is more than I could ask for.

The only drawback for me is that I'll have to get used to your favorites dying D:. There isn't really a set goal besides survival and unlocking all the genes. Some type of story mode that forces more objectives on the player might be helpful, but I enjoy the simulation nature as-is. That is not to say this game isn't challenging, but it something like a sim-city game or a civ game.

37557908.review:
This game is fun and hard at the same time! the point of the game is to keep your pack alive, and travel to distant islands.
here are some tips for new people

1}  Start at the tutorial! the tutorial starts you off with the story of Adam, ( Story Mode is the tutorial )

2} Keep some animals near berry bushes, so every day you can collect enough berries to feed your tribe!

3} use the immunity genes to your advantage, the immunity genes are the letters at the end of the little DNA swirl. if a baby is born with the same immunity genes like G and G or A and A, it has a bigger chance of getting sick. 

4} if two parents have immunity genes like,
EXAMPLE 1)  Father: G and F
Mother: H and G
OR
EXAMPLE 2 ) Father: I and H
Mother: H and G

These couples have a immunity genes in common, for Example 1 the common gene is G, for number 2 it is H.
if the couples had a baby, it could have the chance of having double immunity and a bigger chance of getting sick
EXAMPLE OF DOUBLE IMMUNITY: G and G

Sorry if this confused you but this is how the game works...I recommend this game
thank you for listening 
*bows*

37333758.review:
我很喜歡這種為長遠生存考量的遊戲，
如果你是期待動作緊促的生存遊戲的話，可能真的會覺得有點無聊。

這款遊戲主要是回合制，每隻動物一天有三次的移動機會。
要採集樹果還是追逐獵物?看到掠食者要逃跑還是反擊?
是要節約糧食而減少生育?還是增加族群數量好分頭去尋找資源?
讓你的族員演化成攻擊力高的掠食者型?還是打散成什麼都能做的雜食型?或是能完全仰賴樹果的採集型?
一天能移動的次數雖然就是那麼少，但其實你能走的路很多。
目的只有一個，將你的族群持續的繁殖下去。

小技巧分享
-最好別做作不擅長的事，比如抓魚能力低就別去抓魚(成功機率太低了)
-有生病的動物的話別接近牠，生病在過一個夜後會傳染給鄰近的生物導致壽命降低。
-會生病通常都是由兩個一樣的免疫基因組成，近親繁殖很容易出現。
-如果你有幾隻攻擊能力比較高可以試著去圍毆狼，是個不錯的食物來源。
-注意背景音效，很多事件的發生都可以透過一些音效來發現。
-在水邊要注意寄生蟲，需要另一隻同伴來咬掉牠並幫你止血。
-螃蟹只要在背對著你的時候攻擊才有效，建議用兩隻去圍毆牠xd

37237923.review:
This game is very cute and entertaining. If you like turn-based strategy games, then this is for you. It reminds me a bit of the board game Small World, as well as the video game Don't Starve (which you can also get on steam).  While the game is fairly easy to learn, it can take a while to really master it. 
PROS:
-adorable
-great art
-easy to learn
-sandbox and story mode options
-real genetics!
-great music
-runs well even on weaker computers
CONS:
-can get boring if you aren't a very goal-oriented person. There is only one goal: survive. Once you get the hang of game play, this task is extremely easy. There are achievements and the main "story line" that can be accomplished, but the feeling of having a specific goal to work towards is lacking. Additionally, the story line is simple: you got separated from your tribe and need to go back home. There is no marker on how far along you are towards getting home, and no way to really track your progress. You are either on your home island or not. I would appreciate the game more if there was at least a bar at the top of the screen that showed what percentage of islands you have explored, genes unlocked, and other small goals. A few more larger goals or different story lines would be interesting as well.
-"feminine" game. I wouldn't go so far as to call it girly, but Niche's cuteness is a huge part of the game. Although I'm a girl and happen to love this kind of stuff, some people may be embarrassed to play a "girly" game. 
-no multiplayer options, as of yet. It would be nice to play a multiplayer map, where the goal would be to outlast the other player(s). Maybe they could even work together as a tribe.
-It would also be neat if there was a spore-like create-a-creature option, especially since sandbox mode is hardly a "sandbox" version - it is almost the exact same as story mode, but without the goal of getting home. 

Conclusion:
Cute, simple, and addicting. Overall I would give the game an 8/10 for the average player, or a 9/10 if you enjoy games like Spore, Small World, and Don't Starve. The use of realistic genetics gives Niche a significant amount of depth to it, although the story is weak and the lack of difficult, obvious goals can make the game boring for those who don't enjoy sandbox style games. Kids could play too, although they will need to be able to read and work out a simple strategy. My guess for a minimum age (based on difficulty of the game rather than content) would be 8. I would highly recommend this game to those who like cute, strategy/puzzle, genetic, or survival games. This game would not be enjoyed much by those who prefer realistic art (vs cartoony), action, or a strong push towards completing goals.

36587789.review:
A brilliant little game with many different playstyles and content to explore, Niche has to be one of the most well executed "evolution-esque" survival games out there. The way the game plays out is rather simple; you play as a "tribe" or pack of animals who through breeding can combine their genes with other animals to gain or lose different traits (be that cosmetic or an actual ability). Through selective breeding (or cold hard luck) you can make your species flourish or parish, however, the best part about Niche is that in almost all cases no matter your creature's "stats" (unless they are complete shit and the creature is a complete genetic deformity) you can still survive very long and have fun in varying different ways depending on the way your creature has evolved (water or land?) and how you yourself can adapt and change your playstyle depending on the environment in game, which I found to be very intuitive. One of the things I really hate about other games is how if you are some how out of the "meta" (a certain path the game wants you to take in your playstyle.) the game punishes you. In Niche, that is just not a thing. Keep in mind, though, that if you do act stupid your species will go extinct, which I think is absolutely perfect because the game doesn't exactly hold your hand but still allows for any amount of freedom you'd like in your decisions and choices.

However, like any other game or gene pool, it's not completely perfect. some of the mechanics in the game felt rather annoying or offputting. Disease has to be one of my main gripes. In-game, if one of the members of your pack gets infected with even the common cold, expect it to spread like wildfire. It seems kind of silly to me how fast disease can spread in this game, especially since it can be so lethal. On top of that there is no real way to quarantine anyone away from your main herd or to banish them without risking other pack member's lives in the process. Currently, the only really effective ways I've found of "quarantining" or culling members who are sickly off of my pack are either commanding them to stand in water untill they die of oxygen starvation or just shoving them some random place wayyyy far off in a forest or jungle untill they die from whatever disease they have. This combined with the fact that animals in this game don't live that long anyway and the fact that diseases slowly take away how long animals can survive really drains from the main gameplay. On top of this, some of the traits animals can have are quite annoying to deal with but absolutely avoidable, so just don't breed with freaks and you should be good.

Overall, I'd give this game a 8/10. There are very few gripes I have with the game and overall it is a very enjoyable experience.

36541608.review:
A genetic survival game where you get a certain amount of action points per "animal", per day. Breed male and female and as long as the female is in a nest the next morning she will give birth. Throw in some aggressive creatures roaming about, a few stray animals looking to implant their genes into your pool, the hunt for food, and a bit of island hopping/adventure. That's what you will find in Niche

 It seemed like a no brainer for me when I purchased the game. I had a bit of an impression the game was about cross breeding species, manipulating DNA and having your creatures coexist amongst each other. That is not at all what this game is. The game is about a pack of animals that "struggle" to survive in any given habitat where you breed/manipulate the gene pool to where you feel your pack is evolving.

The main issue I had with the game is the 14ish day/turn life cycle. I found it all too common that once you establish an Alpha (your favorite gene combination) and start to breed it the timer is ticking WAY too fast. I wasn't a fan of the randomness or forever losing the option to breed your alpha again after those 14 days. You get a set amount of rounds to enhance your gene pool and during that time the parents of that animal have died off. If all your attempts don't leave you with a sense of progression towards an ideal combination of genes then you lost your opportunity. You will then have to begin an entire new cycle of mediocre breeding cycles in an attempt to get what you want. 

The RNG is extremely heavy in this game. In the end I am left with a feeling that there isn't any real goal to obtain or any direction to take outside of just finding a solid food source of bushes that respawn food. Establish a renewable food source and the game leaves you with nothing more than breeding for that optimal pack. It is far too easy to lose genes in this process, so that ruined the game for me. I don't want to breed 4 different +1 armor and +4 claws animals with each other and not obtain a single birth that has +1 armor without remapping half of the other genes, while at the same time creating new borns that are by far inferior to their parents. 2 male, 2 female, about 16 children and not a single child I didn't banish from the pack. 

I guess the real issue here is the lack of information or understanding of which genes are dominant and such. It felt awfully random to me and for that reason I am not a fan. For $18.00 idk what I was expecting, but I sure wasn't expecting a game that felt so lacking of content. Maybe I am biased because I see so much potential for this genre. I plan on giving it another run, but the last time I tried I quickly lost interest in trying.

36423810.review:
Niche. Mein absolutes Lieblingsspiel momentan.
Normalerweise mag ich keine rundenbasierten Spiele und sie werden mir schnell langweilig. Anders ist Niche. Ich kann neben dem Spielen nicht einmal eine Serie schauen, weil ich mich so konzentriere. Leider ist das Tutorial recht knapp und erklärt nur die Steuerung und nicht die genetischen Tricks. Das ist schade, weil längst nicht alles selbsterklärend ist, wie die Mutationen. Ich hoffe, es wird dazu noch eine Hilfe-Seite geben, obwohl ich nun (glaube ich), langsam dahinter gestiegen bin. 

Kurze Liste: 
Pros: - kein Limit bei den genetischen Kombinationen
- spannend bleibende Random-Events (immer wenns einem gerade nicht passt!)
- verschiedene Level mit unterschiedlichem Schwierigkeitgrad (wenns langweilig wird, einfach die Insel wechseln - und dort haben deine Tiere random vielleicht keine Chance zu überleben und müssen sich erst anpassen, oder sie rocken das Ding)
- supersüße Grafik
- wenig Bugs
- ordentliche Übersetzung
- angenehme Geräusche (die Niches fiepsen so putzig und die Musik nervt nicht)
- fordernd (man muss wirklich nachdenken, was man wie tut und planen)

Cons: - keine Ziele außer zu überleben
- Auflösung nicht frei skalierbar
- begrenzte Anzahl Speicherplätze
- keine ausgiebige Hilfeseite oder optionales Tutorial
- Gras (es nervt)
- keine Möglichkeit, in einem extra Modul wie Sims, ein perfektes Niche zu erstellen (mich würd einfach interessieren, wie es aussehen könnte - andererseits ist es natürlich auch herausfordernd, das durch "Zufall", die Genetik, rauszukriegen)

Alles in allem ist es perfekt für alle, die auf süße Tierchen, Survivalgames (ohne zu viel Action) und Genetik stehen. Also für mich. Hah!

36381553.review:
This is the kind of game that keeps me up at night.

Even after I've stopped playing, I think about which combinations of traits would create the ideal hunter, how much it's worth it to introduce sub-optimal genes to increase diversity of immunity genes, whether it's worth it to interbreed risking sickness to preserve certain traits, and much more.

I see some people saying this game isn't hard, but it isn't exactly easy either. If you aren't following a user-created guide after the tutorial, you're still going to have hours of learning ahead of you, and quite some time before you master it.

The rules of this game are all fairly simple and logical; you rarely sit around trying to remember how exactly a system works, because things generally work as you'd expect them to. I think the creators of this game have an incredibly solid base from which to further build this game, which brings up my one complaint.

This game is not done. The game's website acknowledges that "releasing" was just an attempt to raise attention and funds to continue development. The features are all there, the basis for the game is there, it just needs some expansion. It boasts over 100 genes to develop your species, but that really isn't as many as it sounds, especially when you include things like colorings, patterns, immunity genes, et cetera. Adding just a few more possibilities for the more functional features like jaws, horns, paws, bodies, tails, et cetera would go a LONG way in expanding this game.

The islands also need to be expanded, or better yet, reworked. The islands essentially serve as levels, the features of the island shaping the difficulty and ideal traits for that playthrough. Adding new island types would be cool, but this game really begs for sliders. Let us pick the climate, the scarcity of food, how hard it is to gather, how heavy on predators it will be, how strong they will be, what types we want to deal with, how many wild animals there are to recruit, et cetera. This is a pretty core feature of sandbox games, and this game feels incredibly sandboxy, so this part kind of seems like a no-brainer, and a mistake/oversight by the developer. Some further customization options like allowing us to alter the lifespan of our animals, our starting resources and our starting trie would also be nice.

All-in-all, I think this game is great as it is, and it has a pretty straightforward path to improvement.

36325532.review:
Niche is ein wirklich liebevoll gestaltetes, rundenbasiertes Strategie Game mit einem Touch Survival und Simulations Touch. Wir übernehmen hierbei die Rolle der Erhaltung einer Art, sowie deren Vermehrung, aber auch was noch interessanter ist, deren DNA Verbesserung. Kurz gesagt: Das Überleben und Weiterentwickeln der Spezies. 

Grafisch ist das Game wirklich eine Augenweide und man merkt defenitiv, das die Entwickler sich hierbei Mühe gegeben haben. Es macht auf jeden Fall Spass mit den Charakteren zu interagieren, die sogar ihre Köpfe nach dem Mauszeiger ausrichten. 

Insgesamt betrachtet, ein Game das sich etwas, von den bereits gewohnten rundbasierten Games, positiv unterscheidet. Es bietet diverse Möglichkeiten seine Art genetisch weiter voran zutreiben, aber ich muss auch fairerweise hinzufügen, ist das Game nicht so einfach wie es am Anfang erscheinen mag. 

Der Schwierigkeitsgrad von Niche ist eher auf schwer einzuordnen. Ohne einen vorrausplanenden Überblick über die Fortplanzung und Weiterentwicklung, kann euere Spezies bald die Radieschen von unten betrachten (sprich sie sterben aus). 

Fazit: Ungeachtet des Schwierigkeitgrads, ein wirklich lohnendes rundenbasiertes Strategiegame. Auf das die Köpfe zu rauchen beginnen XD. Klare Kaufempfehlung für alle die Herrausforderungen lieben.

36312359.review:
The game is just a mess. I don't usually write reviews but this game really struck me the wrong way just because of how excited I was for it and how disappointed I was once I started playing, so here I am. I like to give games a chance before I make a judgement but this just starts off wrong.

The game is tedious, with the gameplay revolving around moving a small selection of spaces and looking for food, or trying to get nesting material, which is slow. The need for food means you'll probably have the majority of your creatures sitting by a bush, using each of their three turns to collect berries.

Your animals die too fast for you to really get a good grasp of the genes, the functionality of them, or make any attachment. I find in games that getting attached to a character or an aspect of gameplay is the best way to really love something and get involved. The breeding system seems to be nothing more than a gimmick to get you to play the game, while the turn system is horribly, terribly bad and doesn't instill a use of strategy, but rather imposes a limit on playability.

The strategy of the game seems to revolve around sitting characters in front of foods and doing nothing with them except gathering, or occassionally moving a group towards a predator and then picking up the food they drop if they die, and then breeding while working still not moving the creatures you have gathering. You'll also battle grass that regrows in a couple of days and hinders your gameplay, while really not granting any substance to the game as a whole. Disease and illness are another thing you'll probably run into, but it doesn't have enough substance (notice a theme yet?) to make gameplay interesting.

The game is not worth $18, its more worth $10, or even $5, considering the content. There is more variety in some mobile games and I feel like this is the type of game you'd find on the app store for $0.99 rather than $18 on Steam. This is probably a good childs education game, if you have an instuctor going over it with them to teach them how genes work at a purely base level, thats about all its good for and thats even a stretch.

Save your money, the combination of a bad breeding system, a gene system where variety comes from a majority of cosmetic changes, and the shortness of not only each creatures turn, but also shortness of your creatures lives, makes this game a hard pass.

Remember the No Man's Sky release and its lack of content? This is it, all over again.

There are only so many things you can do with your species, and the balance between stakes and rewards makes it hard to feel truly invested in their stuggles. And, as much as I want to, I really don't care enough to help them get back out of them again. I'm not invested, though I wish I was. Over all, it's not the worst game in the world, but it's not one that's made for everyone. At the very least, it's not one that holds my interest very well.

Este es un juego que engloba los siguientes elementos: animales, genética y evolución, naturaleza, supervivencia, estrategia por turnos, descubrimiento y exploración. Es definitivamente una combinación única e interesante.

Una vez has jugado lo suficiente y entiendes todas las mecánicas, puedo decir que es un juego bastante disfrutable y adictivo. No me atrevería a meterme en el Metagame para criticar ciertos aspectos, eso se lo dejo a los más metódicos y analíticos. Yo me limito a opinar si me parece divertido/entretenido o no, y en efecto me lo parece.

¿A quien recomendaría este juego? a fans de los juegos de estrategia por turnos que quieran probar algo diferente e innovador. A los fans de los juegos de/con animales y elementos de supervivencia. 36165794.review:
Les graphismes sont plaisants, l'interface est simple et intuitive et l'idée est originale et intéressante.
Déjà, quand je jouait aux Sims 2 c'est la génétique qui m'intéressait et je m'amusait des heures à regarder les gènes se transmettre aux sims de différentes générations.
Cependant, contrairement aux Sims 2 où on pouvait régler la durée de vie des personnages, les animaux de Niche ont une longévité beaucoup trop courte selon moi. 25 jours c'est trop peu. Ça oblige à une frénésie de procréation qui fait qu'on est vite perdu dans la masse de rejetons et qu'on a du mal à bien intégrer tous les aspects de cette génétique qu'on essaie de contrôler.
Un réglage dans les paramètres devrait permettre de régler cette longévité. On pourrait alors prendre le temps de jouer, de s'attacher à ses personnages, de choisir une lignée à développer et faire des essais de toutes sortes sans voir nos premiers géniteurs disparaître au bout de quelques minutes de jeu. 
De plus, les maladies se développent beaucoup trop aléatoirement. Elles devraient résulter d'une mauvaise gestion de nos personnages par rapport à leur environnement. 
Ce jeu a du potentiel. Je suis certaine que je pourrais l'adorer, mais pour le moment, il me laisse un peu sur ma faim.
Malgré tout, je le recommande; le jeu est bien fait, les graphismes sobres, la musique relaxante. C'est un mignon passe-temps, en attendant que les développeurs ajoutent ces fonctions qui le rendront plus personnalisable.

I received a code for this game and I started playing it immediately. I've played it for 55 hours because I fell in love with it. It's basic strategy and fast paced, plus it's super cute!

If you haven't gotten the idea from other reviews or the info, you have to cross breed animals to keep a tribe alive while breeding out bad qualities and keeping/attaining good qualities!

Although it can get repetitious at times (keep breeding, keep harvesting, repeat) there are various trials that shake things up, plus the perfectionist in me wants to get various types of animals that all look a certain way.

36130116.review: Really fun game surrounding genetics and surviving / evolving. This game isn't super easy and it doesn't spell everything out for you. It definitely takes some exploring and trial and error. If you need hand holding or a straight forward game, this might be too difficult for you. My animals have died out many times, and that's ok. Its fun to try and breed out weak genes and explore new places. There isn't really an end game goal here. You are just challenging yourself and trying to survive. Any goals are self imposed, such as creating that creature that looks just the way you want, or has the "perfect" combination of genes that you want/need. There are definitely some cool combinations out there. The Devs are really connected with the community and there are still many additions to the game that have been discussed. I am excited to see where this game goes and how it will grow.

1) я сyмела более-менее закрепить желаемый тип внешности и способностей и весь подбор сводился к соотношению бyковок. Вроде того, что: ...И вот y потрясающего самца остался один день жизни и срочно с ближайших концов карты созываем подходящих самок... :D Или наоборот, до последнего самка с нyжными генами живет по схеме самец-гнездо-самец-гнездо и, в конце концов, она приносит ночью последнее дитя и тyт же рассыпается костями прямо на едва открывшихся глазах крохи... :"C Процесс скрещивания интересен, пока есть какой-то вызов, когда еще есть неоткрытые, но желаемые части тела или они вот только недавно открыты и еще не вошли, как доминантный/единственный ген. Спyстя неск островов размер перемещаемой стаи вполне позволяет вести два параллельные ветви (земные/боевые и, например, водные), но я интереса в этом не yвидела. 
2) Однообразные острова. Начиная с первого-семейного я прошла стаей yже около 10 осторов и они все однообразные. Нy где жаркий климат, где холод, где животных приходилось бы перестраивать или постоянно yчитывать позицию для согрева? Одна зеленая трава с ягодами и кроликами/кротами. И сколько мне еще островов надо пройти своей родной стаей, чтобы полyчить новый контент?
И в одном из отзывов в качестве недостатка было названо отсyтствие мyльтиплеера и я с этим полностью согласна! Битва за ресyрсы или параллельные пyти развития нескольких стай, каждый в своей нише. А еще можно было бы использовать или портить гены чyжой стаи - подкрадываться самцом/самкой к чyжомy производителю и в зависимости от пола можно было бы привнести/yнести, а в зависимости от генофонда разбавить попyляцию новыми интересными генами или наплодить изначально больных yродцев. Ввести возможность мyльтиплеера спyстя три-четыре изначальных острова, где можно встретить только npc для принятия в стаю/спаривания (стандартно, как сейчас) и более-менее закрепить свой генофонд, чтобы бороться за него или изменяться под воздействием конкyрентов. Проблема ходов решалась бы выделением определенного времени "дня", где одновременно, чем больше стая, тем ты гораздо лyчше можешь контролировать картy, но одновременно тебе еще за короткое время нyжно yспеть раздать всем в стае действия, сообразить кого с кем спаривать, кого изгнать и т.д... В общем, сейчас можно нафанатазировать новый No mans sky от мира Sporе, но это все равно скорее всего останется только мечтами. Какой-то мyльтиплеер (или хотя бы конкyрентные компьютерные стаи) имело смысл вводить на старте игры, а не сейчас, когда люди yже достаточно натыкали зверюшек и многие yже подзабили(подзабыли даже) этy проходнyю игрy. К томy же, с таким маленьким набором генов yстраивать что-то подобное в любом слyчае нет.
Итог: Сколько-то игровых/часов сyток вы проведете с yдовольствием, потом следyет вероятная потеря интереса. Советовала бы приобретать игрy только если осознаете ее кратковременнyю пользy в качестве yбивалки времени. Оценка стоимости игры не так однозначна, в зависимости от вашего собственного отношения к подобномy типy игр. Посмотрите среднее время, проведенное в игре среди написавших отзывы и оцените, готовы ли за столько часов СВОЕЙ игры отдать полнyю стоимость или предпочтете дождаться скидки.

I backed this game ages ago and I'm extremely happy with it so far. There is a lot to do and it offers hours and hours of playability.  That being said I have a few issues with the game. The largest one being that every single island I've ever been to seems to be nothing but tall grass. One thing that could be done to improve the game would be being able to rotate the map. It would make it possible to see some of the things that are on lower levels at the edges of islands. 

Overall a fantastic game and I would recommend it to anyone who wants to kill hour after hour exploring/breeding/trying to create different species of creature.
