35932729.review:
This is a casual survival game. The game has a good core: the genetic mechanics are well-developed, but the gameplay built around it is lacking content both in breadth and depth. You can only play the 'nicheling', the cutesy creature you see in the game's screenshots; you can make your nicheling be more aquatic, more of a hunter or more of a prey that gathers fruit and nuts, but you will never be at the top of the food chain or sustain your entire colony without berries, fish or nuts. Food doesn't spoil, it is infinite, and stored everywhere at the same time. You don't have hitpoints, you have lifespan, and strikes reduce it. The mechanics are still too simple.

If you are very curious about the setting, do try the game, but if you don't get very much into it within the first 2 hours, refund it; you saw everything you needed to see in those two hours.

35927375.review: It was not what I had expected and it quickly got boring. The game didn't set you up to play very well and I found it difficult to use the in game menus because I didn't know what to press and click.

35922210.review:
[quote][url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/11769719/]Больше качественных и интересных обзоров на кураторской страничке Dreams of Genesis.[/url][/quote]

[h1]Звериная "Цивилизация"[/h1]

[b]Придумать что-то интересное в жанре, в котором уже всё давным-давно придумано – настоящее искусство. Очень трудно что-то изобретать , ведь куда ни плюнь – везде уже это было. Но разработчики Niche - a genetics survival game подумали, что было бы не плохо, если бы во что-то старое добавить парочку капель чего-то нового. И они оказались совершенно правы.   [/b]

Niche - a genetics survival game – это выживастик с элементами симулятора и стратегии. В наши руки попадает милый зверёк по имени Адам, который должен основать своё племя зверей и развивать его, будучи в нём единственным самцом. Казалось бы: ерунда, но не тут то было. Игра очень глубокая с точки зрения игрового процесса. Самое главное тут – параметры, которых очень много. В учёт нужно брать навыки зверей, их иммунитет, болячки и так далее. Наш Адам может набирать в своё племя огромное количество самок, дабы размножаться, но при этом стоит думать о том, чтобы не набирать всех подряд, ибо не хватит еды. Для того, чтобы расширить своё племя – нужно брать тех самок, у которых имеется прокачанный навык добычи еды. И так тут во всём. Если вы не будете думать минимум на четыре хода вперёд – вы очень быстро проиграете. Да, именно хода. Игра построена на механике всем знакомой цивилизации: делится на клеточки, по которым можно ходить. Большинство клеток пусты, но на некоторых можно совершать  определённые действия: ловить рыбу, собирать ягоды и так далее. В день даётся четыре хода, за которые нам нужно обеспечить своё племя провизией, ибо в противном случае они начнут дохнуть. И вот тут и кроется элемент, из-за которого я настоятельно рекомендую думать на четыре, а то и на больше ходов вперёд. Вы можете понадеяться на то, что за четыре хода вы соберете из ближайшего дерева пару ягод и прокормите своё племя. Но вот беда – дерево может оказаться пустым, и вы начнёте загибаться от голода. И подобных ситуаций очень много, из-за чего играть в данный продукт очень интересно. 

Помимо режима песочницы, в который вы можете играть пока не надоест, или же пока вы все не умрёте, есть тут и сюжетный режим. История расскажет нам историю нашего Адама. Познакомит нас с его семьёй, расскажет, как он оказался один и как он начал строить своё племя. История не шибко интересная, но в качестве приятного бонуса – сойдёт. В конце то концов, основной акцент всё же делается на режим песочницы. 
С точки зрения графического исполнения – всё довольно таки неплохо. Милая картинка, отлично прорисованные клеточки, высокий уровень детализации и симпатичное общее впечатление. Ни единого нарекания на картину нет. Оптимизация хорошая, интерфейс тоже видно здорово, все кнопки расположены на видном месте и не нужно рыскать по экрану в их поисках. Со звуком тоже всё предельно хорошо. Неплохой саундтрек, который играет где-то на заднем плане расслабляет и заставляет погружаться ещё глубже в местную атмосферу. 
Ну и ещё из приятного хотелось бы отметить полную русскую локализацию. Спасибо разработчикам за это, ибо в подобные игры без знания языка играть просто нереально. С моим уровнем английского я бы точно не справился. 

Что же я могу сказать? Да всё хорошо. Неплохая замена всем надоевшей «Цивилизации». Много параметров, много аспектов, приятный баланс, симпатичная графика и неплохая общая концепция. В общем, любителям жанра однозначно рекомендую. Если же вы не играли ни во что подобное – тоже можете смело брать, так как для знакомства с такими играми – самое оно. Но только помните: не берите в племя кого попало. Некоторые самки могут быть заразными и будут распространять инфекцию. 

[h1]Общая оценка: 8/10[/h1]

35808113.review:
I thoroughly enjoy this as a game, and in my opinion I got my money's worth for it. It's enjoyable, and I put entirely too much time into it and realised far too often that it was suddenly 2am when I had to be awake for something in five hours.

I have to stress that this is a casual game. There's no real hard-core survival mechanics built into it, it's not "if you don't do everything EXACTLY CORRECT your chances to live are slim". You can build up food very quickly if you gene right for it, and I often had populations of creatures on an island in the 30-60 range. Once you have the set-up for an island and the genes unlocked, surviving is rather simple (barring some of the harder islands). If you're looking for something with a lot of challenge consistently through the game, this is probably not for you.

That said, the learning curve can be high if you decide to start on a medium or higher island - without the genes you normally need to survive those islands, you can very, very easily end up going extinct.

The real draw is the genetics manipulation. I liken this game to a builder in that aspect - I'm not trying to survive (that's an initial goal that becomes less important the more you're succeeding), I'm trying to create a creature that looks a certain way or is prepared for a certain kind of island. Or I'm just breeding in random genes to see what the resulting creature ends up looking like! It's all about what you want to do.

Which is my next point: there isn't really a 'goal' in Niche. The story mode gives you an option to try and strive for, as you start as Adam who's been taken from his home and you can try and get your creatures to get back there over the generations. But the game doesn't end there, and you don't even have to do it if you don't want to. Niche is a game that lets you decide what you want to do. It's open-ended, and that's usually the reason so many of the major Let's Players of this game are storytellers - they're creating more depth to a game that's allowing for inspiration to be taken and run with into whatever you want it to. You can make it easier or harder on yourself with your own rules - think Pokemon Nuzlock challenges. You can do similar challenges here.

There are some issues that still need resolving, I won't pretend that there isn't. The tutorial isn't that great, it's extremely basic and doesn't go into the genetics, which are the core of the game. There are bugs here and there, but to the dev team's credit, they're doing their best to try and fix them as they show up. Achievements in particular are bugged as of my posting this. The challenge of the game does diminish as you get better genes, and it turns from survival into whatever you want to do, which isn't bad but having something that remains tricky to deal with throughout the game would be nice. The music is also very repetitive the longer you spend on an island. I don't dislike it, but when I can spend 3-5 hours session on one island, it's incredibly boring after the first half hour.

All in all, it's a very enjoyable game in my opinion, and I whole-heartedly recommend it.

7.5/10 Would recommend

You start as a little creature on a deserted Island. As you change islands, you invite other nichlings you ecounter to your pack and mate with them, mixing and matchings genes to have the best offspring possible. Sometimes you get lucky, sometimes you don't, but ultimalty it's up to you to breed your nichlings in the best possible way to fit your environment, collect food and avoid illness. 

Cons:
- Learning curve a bit steep  ( I personally thought it made the game more interesting that way. You learn by trial and error. )
- Tutorial a bit unclear ( I didn't mind the tutorial not showing you exactly how the genes work, but it doesn't really show you any of the mechanics of the game expect for how to move the camera )

Pros:
- Original idea ( Mix of genetics and survival, I've never played anything like this before, even Spore )
- Great replay value ( Every game starts with different islands, different nichligs you ecounter, no 2 games are exactly the same)
- Not too easy ( After 8 hours of game time, it gets easier but there's definitely still challenge in figuring out your moves )
- Very relaxing, good soundtrack
- Looks good but still runs like a charm on my old computer

35492345.review:
[h1]Niche：当生存和遗传学相结合[/h1]

打分：8/10 (9/10，减一分是因为我觉得这个游戏歧视生物学渣……QAQ)

[h1]优点[/h1]

+ 可爱的画风
+ 生态遗传知识和游戏融合的很棒，通俗易懂
+ 操作简单
+ 大自然是很残酷的，你需要学会放弃、驱逐或杀死同类；但同时也可以对弱小的同类更多的宽容和保护
+ 游戏前期很有趣，需要不断的进行尝试来探索
+ 生物遗传的无限可能性

[h1]缺点[/h1]

- 后期枯燥，随机性不足
- 有中文，但是是机翻，且错误非常多(连商店页面的介绍都有错误)
- 在族群动物数过多时，没有UI可以反映哪些有过行动而哪些没有
- 族谱太过复杂，优生优育时提供参考的作用很小
- 提示不足，很多方向需要玩家自己探索(这就是为什么说需要一定的生物遗传知识)
- 游戏整体节奏缓慢

[h1]其他[/h1]

+/- 虽然是大自然的生态学，但基本只能发展繁衍出四肢爬行的哺乳类动物，形似狐狸抑或猫科，玩家是不可能繁衍出长颈鹿的，孔雀猴子也不用想。但相对来说，保证了基因的一致性，顶多繁衍出一个四不像而不是一个外星生物
+/- 虽然操作简单，但玩的很溜很难，感觉还是需要一定的生物知识打
+/- 后期游戏难度在不断增加
+/- 这个游戏真正有趣的地方在于不断的交配繁衍，而不在生存

[h1]游戏tips[/h1]

1.	近亲交配是不可避免的，放心大胆的去做吧！(等到了后期在慢慢优生优育)
2.	下雨天交配会增加产子的生病率
3.	虽然没有统计数据，但引入外来物种并不会明显的减少生病几率
4.	善用不同的五官来观察世界，用你的视觉、嗅觉和听觉
5.	不要招大小眼的同类！大小眼绝对是显性基因！
6.	事实上并不需要刻意积攒筑巢的材料，每个地图都有自带的巢；但除草(除草是获得筑巢材料的主要途径)能扩大可视范围和可行动范围
7.	在后期的新地图，注意莓果丛和毒莓果丛的区别。
8.	成员受伤或者染上寄生虫后让其他的成员及时舔舐，可以去除debuff
9.	狼来了不要怂，三个成员围上去一个来几爪，很快就死了，而且获得的肉也多
10.	不要和螃蟹纠缠
11.	有成员生病时，如果无法及时治疗(地图上没有药果丛)，远离它或者杀死它(这很残忍，是的)
12.	不需要刻意追赶兔子，游戏里食物获取的最佳途径是蹲果丛
13.	多多繁衍有采集能力的后代，如果它的采集能力很弱，让它去做探索的任务

[h1]小故事分享[/h1]

1.在我的某一档中，我繁衍了数代，在族群交配之后，突然我得到了一个带着扁嘴(鸭嘴)的幼崽Nununu、当时就黑人问号？？？？它的父母都没有这个特征呀？
然后突然想起，在某某一代，我貌似招进来了一个带鸭嘴的同类，于是第一次认真的看了看族谱，果然，那位早已死去的先辈(Raisra)，安安静静的躺在族谱的最上端。
在经历了这么多代后，突然就在一个后辈身上继续出现了这种特征，实在是让人觉得很有趣的一件事。
不知道这叫隔代遗传呢，还是返祖呢www

2.我的族群里出现了一个盲眼特征的幼崽，它的行动区域是3，但它的可视区域只有1。
在游戏里，可视区域是可以拓展的，即，当你的族群人员分布在相对合适的位置时，你的可视范围因为共享而大大增加，这一大块区域，就是游戏里的白色区域(视力范围)。
犹豫了一下，看看食物并没有缺乏，就没有将它驱逐，而是让它呆在了族群里，想着让它就呆在果丛旁边采果子都行。
我的族群的其他成员在不断向另一个方向迁徙，很快，这个盲眼仔就被遗忘在了后面，由于没有处在白色区域里，它的可视区域又只有1，即便是在它旁边的格子里的果丛它都看不见(可视区域只有1代表它只能“看到”它所呆着的的那一个格子)。
想了想，派了个成员到了它旁边，共享了彼此的可视区域，盲眼仔虽然目不能视，但它优秀的行动步伐很快就跟上了大部队。
后来族群迁徙到了另一个小岛，它也是其中一员。
最后一天，它的生命走到了尽头，它趴在地上，寿终安寝。
再见，盲眼仔。

[h1]购买建议[/h1]

生态学遗传学大佬可以购买，从中说不定可以体会到专业人士才能感受到的乐趣
如果对随机尝试的游戏有偏爱，很推荐这个游戏
如果仅仅是有兴趣的话建议观望一阵或先看看实况，因为游戏后期实在无聊，基因配对发展的回合数偏多，虽然已经过了EA阶段，游戏内容还是偏少，期待游戏不断的更新

[h1]总结[/h1]

这是一个很独特的游戏，因为带有生态遗传标签的游戏实在太少了，出现一款也很让人感兴趣。
游戏方式主要是回合制，成年动物有3个行动点数，活动范围(可行走最远的格子数)在1~3之间，同时它们也有可视范围，而可视范围是共享的。在游戏里，你的族群成员保证足够分散又足够紧密，便可以随意在岛上行动。
食物的获取主要莓果丛、橡果树、抓鱼、狩猎
你的敌人只有狼，荆棘，毒莓果丛，还有会把幼崽抓走的鸟(不过出现很少)
要我说，这个游戏更倾向于益智类，游戏介绍说它参考了孢子和饥荒，事实上是把孢子的基因组合和饥荒的采集结合了起来---基因组合上，并不是随心所欲的，这很棒，我玩的是一个繁衍游戏而不是一个创造外星人游戏；生存上，需要的是前期有耐心的积累。
依然是和很不错的游戏，主要是把游戏性和学习性结合的很好，寓教于乐。

(随便求增加结局评价呀，至少让我知道我是怎么死的……

35450871.review:
For those of us who remember Creatures or parts pf Spore, Niche will feel familiar in some aspects. I know that there isn't a huge playerbase for a type of game like this, a strategy/genetics/survival hybrid, but it's a very underserved market and this game goes to great lengths to fill a lot of those missing pieces. If you came for anything other than breeding cute animals and watching them all die out because you fail as their God, then you are more than welcome to find another game to play.

Niche could use a few more perks and maybe a introductory tutorial on how the genetics work, but if you remember Creatures, that didn't come with a tutorial either and you probably figured it out over time. This game encourages you in much the same way. 'Here's the tools, here's the bare minimum to get by, make your own fun'. In the entirely good way. I'd like to see this title continue to grow even after full release, as the current project is very enjoyable and perfect for that niche audience of animal/monster breeders.

35403715.review:
I've put an alright amount of hours into this, and I think it's about time to say what I think about this game.

Niche is for exactly the kind of playerbase it says - a niche market. Most people probably will find this game boring or repetitive, and at times, it is. It's a game I like to play when my friends are telling stories or I'm listening to a podcast. It doesn't take much concentration, but still just enough overall to keep me playing.

I have still yet to beat story mode, as the game can be surprisingly difficult at times. Mostly it's slowly moving your way through an area and just collecting food or trying to survive, but every now and then there is that panic and rush for more food or a suffient mate to carry on your tribe's legacy. This game is right about making it hard to survive very long, because it's a genetics game. Lots of things don't work. I LIKE that about the game. It makes it feel very important to pay attention to little things in your tribe's gene pool, and you have to consider what needs to change to improve survival. But usually, things aren't that easy. You'll come across a lot of weird future mates in the wild, and have no choice but to try your luck with them. Usually, it ends up in more oddities that need to be fixed in future generations. And don't even get me started on Rogue Males. Please, guys. Leave my females alone. We don't have enough food for more babies that will end up being made Omegas.

When I first saw this game my instant thought was "huh, so this is a furry game, right?" and yeah. I kinda is. If that is something you refuse to deal with, then I guess this game isn't for you. The way the animals look all together is just very, uh, furry-ish? But I've come to think it very charming, and start to understand why some people who play the game like to add their own lore / story to their tribes.

On the topic of adding your own lore, sometimes I wonder if that's how the game is meant to be played. The gameplay is repetitive and kind of dull after a few hours, which makes sense being a genetics game where your goal is to simply survive, but it gets a little stale. I think people add stuff to their playthroughs to spice it up, and that's cool! I'm not so good at assigning random lore to my tribes, personally. Because that one Rogue Male will come up and breed with all of my females, and I'll be at kind of a loss for how I can make that a cool part of my story.

This game is, hmm, it's hard to say if I actually recommend it. Since it gets stale and the entire game is VERY much for a niche market (which consists of furries, people who played spore as kids, or a combination of both). For people who are PART of that market, go buck-wild, my friends. It leaves some stuff to be desired, but it's a solid enough game in itself for me to not regret getting it. But I know A LOT of my friends would really not find any fun in the game, and that's important to keep in mind before making the purchase.

All in all, it's good enough to keep my attention. I'm looking forward to possble future updates that will spice up the gameplay a bit more. The art and music is fine the way it is, so gameplay is all I'm looking forward to being improved, even if just a little. I think the game would benefit from random events, even if its extreme stuff like "oh hey look at that, a meteor. Have fun trying to survive that!". I think the game would be a lot more appealing with that kind of thing added! I personally enjoy the game, so I recommend it, but maybe look into it before you make the purchase.

35344845.review: Reminiscent of EVO or Spore in some aspects, though set up as a turn based strategy game. The gameplay itself is fairly simple, as you move around and find different ways to acquire enough food to survive and fight off other creatures or environmental extremes. The fun is obviously in breeding animals together in order to provide you with animals better able to adapt to their surroundings. There's a strong amount of variety in the different types of genes available, which you control to some extent by selective breeding, inviting wild creatures into your pack, and through small amounts of manual choice. Acquiring new environments and unlocking genes that you can steer animals towards keeps things fresh. Lots of fun for someone interested in biology or genetics in particular. Highly recommended!

35329393.review:
I went into this game blind, having only seen a few screenshots. It blew me away. I was expecting some low quality SPORE ripoff, and what I found was an incredibly deep hex grid survival RPG hybrid. My goal going in was to create some kind of cute fox creature and scavenge corpses to survive. I had no idea that I would be evolving my cute little foxes into gill-necked sharkfoxes with raccoon hands for opening shellfish on the ocean floor, with hooked tails suited to catching fish and webbed feet for faster swimming. Likewise, I had no idea that an hour later I would be scrambling to splice in fennec fox style giant ears to survive a savannah archipelago that was being rapidly consumed by cleansing fire. I played this game until my computer melted, and was hyped the whole time. My 20 day lifespan foxes struggled constantly on the razor's edge of the knife which is extinction, and I learned how to handle new threats just to allow defenses against old threats to be lost to the generations. It was amazing.

My only complaint: The tutorial is mostly nonexistent, making your first playthrough basically a forfeit dash towards extinction. I was about 4 hours in before I started to understand the mutation/heredity system, which wasn't explained at all. It shows you how to move, pick berries, and befriend another fox, and then you're on your own. Good luck. You'll need it, and probably die anyway, and it will be totally worth the experience.

35314698.review:
Et ça me désole un peu de mettre un avis négatif, mais j'avais promis de faire une évaluation de ce jeu

Ce jeu est vraiment plus de l'ordre du rogue like que du simulateur de vie et de génétique. Pire, j'ai l'impression que ça n'en n'est qu'un pretexte

Le jeu est a la fois rempli de vides, et a la fois complèxe en terme de mélange génétiques. On se dit qu'on aura le temps de le découvrir et de bien le manier petit a petit, mais ce n'est pas le cas, c'est beaucoup trop hasardeux, c'est dommage !

Ce qui m'a aussi frappé, c'est le mode histoire qui se retrouve au final être trop facile et répétitif, et un mode bac a sable qui se trouve être bien bien plus difficile !

Comme relevé précédement, c'est un jeu qui aurait du être bien mieux develloppé, J'ai la frustration de ne pas avoir des bestioles plus adaptés a leur environnement après plusieurs heures de jeu et surement plusieurs dizaine de génération. C'est peut être un manque de maitrise, mais je n'ai pas la patience. Je l'ai eu pendant 7 heures pour le mode histoire, pas plus ! Car oui, c'est un jeu qui demande de la patience. Le tour par tour est justifié, mais quand le jeu est facile, vous allez avoir tendance a faire beaucoup de créatures et donc vous allez devoir chacune leur demander 3 action chacune, ainsi un seul tour peut durer longtemps, et une créature en bonne santé peut vivre une grosse vingtaine de tours !

C'est plus de l'ordre de "Je place tel et tel bestiole ici et la" Vous allez rapidement comprendre que la meilleur technique, c'est de mettre, une femelle constament au nid, les bêtes les plus nazes, près des buissons pour cueillir des fruits, et un ou deux voir plus qui explorent

J'y retournerais surement pour des parties que je ne "terminerais" jamais. L'ennuis dans ce type de jeu, c'est que puisque c'est du procédural, ça ne se termine jamais. Donc il faut se poser soi même des objectifs, et ces objectifs, les heureux hasard de la nature font qu'on ne les obtiens jamais.

Il manque des choses a ce jeu, ne serait ce que par exemple avoir des clan de bestioles a part, vous êtes les seules bestiolles qui semblent savoir créer un nid et se reproduire ensemble. Un tuto plus poussé serait le bienvenu aussi En faite, il manque des mini boucles de gameplay, ou disons plutôt, des récompenses plus fréquente pour le joueur. Les seules récompenses qu'il a, c'est celui d'avoir enfin après 3 génération une bestiole qui a 4 en cueillette de fruit

Et a coté de ça, les points positifs les graphismes se suffisent même si ça semble brouillon, la génération des iles ont du charme, il y a une bonne variété d'éléments (encore faut t'il les trouver et ne pas tomber sur les mêmes) La musique est la même avec des variation d'instruments et de mélodies selon les biomes des iles. Et tout de même, ça a du charme d'enfin mettre un nid dans les hautes herbes et demander au reste de la famille de desherber a coté. Aussi, c'est assez rigolo au début de se souvenir a quel point la nature peut être cruelle entre les accouplements dans la famille et les mâles érant qui squattent

En bref, un jeu qui a manqué beaucoup d'occasions d'être digne de ce qu'il veut être, qui donc ne vaut pas son prix, dont l'issue est aussi beaucoup trop hasardeux même après des heures de jeu.

It's cute, simple, and usually pretty relaxed; I say usually because once you've done some traveling to the other islands, the environments and predators can make keeping your nichelings alive a bit trickier. The variety of traits you can get from the environment, hybrids, or prehistoric finds keep it interesting. It also helped me scratch that Creatures/Spore itch pretty well. 

I'm kinda hoping they release an expansion or two with more traits/islands or maybe expand on the story to make it more substantial, but for what it is, I thoroughly enjoy it, would recommend it, and am excited to see what else the developers can put out in the future.

35260160.review:
6.5/10, but would recomend!

You start off with 1 critter named Adam who is kidnapped from his pack by a bird of prey. He escapes by lashing out at the beast during a storm and lands on an island. Though you are not alone for long, you find a female named Eve and become mates. The game gives you two goals: Find adam's original pack and/or start your own pack and grow.

---

The art is wonderfully done and the basic control mechanics are simple. However, the game's tutorial is lackluster beyond that. The game really throws you to the wolves with some mechanics that you learn by trial and error. Each creature is given several traits and genes and it shows you can mate to pass them on, yet it doesn't fully break it down. Some creatures are able to swim, but when I moved them into a water tile I soon learned that some of the tiles are considered to be 'under water' and they would still take damage.  

It really feels like an adventure for your cats as the generations pass and you learn the ins and outs. Once you figure out a way to manage your food source and deal with  the random events, the game snowballs in your favor.  It also started to lose that 'adventure' gleam and feels more 'sandboxy' as I found the last bit of content and came up with ideas of how to play the game to give longer replayability.

The menus are organized and intuative, but I have a yearning for more. When you get more than 10+ cats I'm wishing there was an in game tables to view and organize all my felines: I find myself needing to pause and take inventory of my cat's current genes and abilities about every 12 or so turns as their life spans are around 20 days. A table page would definently give me some ease of life as my current pride is 30 cats and I'm spending so much time organizing now. 

A day counter is a MUST. After I unlocked the days survived achievements I no longer have any idea what day I am on in future runs. I hope to see one added in the future. 

Though the game is far from perfect, I have enjoyed my experience. Definently a Niche game that many will love. The game is quite the gem that has loads of potential and I hope to see it continue to evolve into a bigger and better game.

- The variety of "play styles" based on the interaction between genetics and the local environment make me desperate to try EVERYTHING.
- The genetic mechanics, in general, are obtuse and complicated, just like real life! (I graduated with a degree in Biology, so the complexity and detail and the sheer amount of research and time that went into crafting the genetic mechanics are ENTIRELY appreciated and I love every bit of it. This is what pushed the game from "huh, cool nature sim" to "MUST BUY NOW.")

Meh

- Sandbox is great, but I love a good optional story mode. The Adam story is mostly a brief tutorial, which would be fine if there was a more substantial tool tip system or Help menu that didn't open up to a webpage.
- There is a mysterious absence of hotkeys, other than the map modes.

Bad

- You know how there's a column of all your household Sims on the left of the Sims screen? This game doesn't have that. Finding a lost/forgotten animal requires actual searching (damn you, tall grass!) or cycling through with tab. It is infuriatingly slow and a Sims-like display (menu?) of all your living tribe members would be awesome. There's plenty of room on the screen!
- I mentioned the Adam story mode previous as a Meh, but I really, really want more objectives outside of Steam achievements. I'm at a loss for ideas though so I can't blame the developers...

35234993.review:
It's fun and actually not that hard once you get the hang of the system. Breed like rabid, get a few viable breeding families with different immunity genes, and populate the map. While doing so you do your best to eliminate weak genes via selective breeding.

The game's biggest flaw in my opinion is a lack of any automation. The best part of the game is when you migrate to an island and struggle to find your niche and adapt to the environment with a small tribe. However, once you grow, most of your time will be spent tab-clicking the same food resources for hours on end. It's quite a slog, and unfortunately where most of your gameplay time will be spent, while all you really want to do is focus on the genetics aspect of the game.

Other than that, it's a fun critter game with a lot of variety in environments and traits. A little pricey for what it offers though. Wait for a sale.

35226857.review:
The game mechanics are complex but easy to understand if you take one minute or two to assimilate them.

It gives you an idea of how complex genetics are.

The designers also build their game in a way that it opens doors for expansions (not just tiny dlcs that adds stuff, but big expansions).

It is not an easy game, especially if you do not take that one or two minute to understand how things works.

The tutorial is rather small, I would include an entire part to the genetics and how it works in the game. For example, the tutorial does not tell you how to get rid of trraits you do not want in your breed nor does it tell you how to develop new traits. Since this is a genetics game, why is the tutorial deprived of any genetic-related instructions? It's sad.

The story mode should be by steps, each time you change island, you should get another story part, giving you hints where your family is. That way, you can either follow your own path or seek your old family.

On more superficial, and unimportant for me, aspects of the game...
- The graphics are nice and cute.
- Music is pleasant, but I would add more tracks in its first big expansion
- Sounds are also entertaining.


I strongly recommand this game to everyone. It is well worth its price, and if it is on sale jump on it. It is relaxing yet not too easy. Just take two minutes to learn how the genetics work and keep an eye on those genes so that you do not get sickly descendants.

35212948.review:
Rating: 6.5/10

I want to like this game [b]SO[/b] badly, but unfortunately it leaves a lot to be desired. I simply can't recommend this game as it is. I would love to see the developers continue to work on this game, or produce a vastly more complex version.

The core theme of the game is fantastic, and I believe that the developers are truly onto something, but as it currently is It feels much more like a demonstration on genetics, or educational game for young kids rather than a complete game. If you are buying it for these purposes then its definitely suitable. As someone looking for a complete game with objective, progression, complexity, "win condition", challenge, sense of accomplishment, or possibly even limitless creativity the game is not fulfilling. Despite these flaws I maintain a positive outlook on the game, because I can imagine that in the right hands this game could be incredible. With that said I am not going to pull any punches, and I want to address the things this game lacks, which would otherwise make it a 10/10 title in my opinion. 

[b]Automation[/b]: One of my biggest complaints is that every single turn I need to perform the exact same collection actions to harvest nuts and berries. This task is tremendously mundane when you have fully a colonized island. Hundreds of turns of harvesting berries and nuts over and over is super boring. Automatically performing collection duties eliminates this unreasonably tedious chore, and allows the player to focus on the genetics aspect of the game. 

[b]Specialization[/b]: There is very little demand for specialization. 
-Going beyond +2 collecting is more of a mechanical luxury because you get to click less. 
-Basically no advantage to going beyond +1 cracking, because it's sufficient to break acorns. 
-Fishing is a terrible and poorly balanced mechanic, which probably results in net food loss anyways. 
-The only DEMAND for specialization is in temperature resistance, which I'll say in some ways is decently balanced.
-Although there is a lot of opportunity to specialize in combat strength, it's much easier to just poison something or avoid it entirely.

[b]Mutation[/b]: The mutation menu should be removed from the game. All genetics should be worked toward as a product of random mutations and cross breeding with foreign nichelings. The mutation menu is a lame mechanic that encourages stockpiling of food on noob islands, while still getting any genetics you want. It eliminates the need for travel, exploration, and adaptation to unfavorable environments. Similarly the idea of being able to bring as much food as you want to the next island is ridiculous. Food reserve should have a hard cap upon traveling based on difficulty or something. 

[b]Advancement[/b]: There is no actual advancement of genes. Evolution of genetics often occurs as a product of internal competition of a species. The fastest, strongest, and smartest animals are the ones that continue to reproduce. There should be traits that are OBJECTIVELY superior to others. For example, consider a claw hierarchy of Super Sharp Claws > Sharp Claws > Claws > Dull Claws. This gives players incentive to continue to push forward, and to temporarily find value in a terrible attribute like Dull Claws since it takes a large number of generations to get a lucky mutation toward regular Claws. To elaborate I think the 'ancient' genetics should have to be worked toward, and should be monumentally more rewarding. 

[b]Variation[/b]: Barring aesthetics the amount of genetic diversity is fairly trivial in my opinion. I would love to see this game implemented with 10+ viable traits per gene, with tiers of functionality, as explained in the last point. Instead most traits are relatively binary in the sense that the trait is either good or crippling. For example, there are only 3 eye traits in the game, and in no circumstance would I suggest making your nichelings blind or short sighted, thus regular eyesight is the only reasonable choice, and since it's unlocked at the start of the game it is quite easy to eradicate these undesirable genes.

[b]Objective[/b]: There should be certain challenges that require you to make very 'niche' nichelings. For example maybe a mega predator, that will reward your nichelings if defeated, but cannot be damaged by any nichelings that lack maximum physical strength. Similarly challenges like a part of the map that is so cold that a nicheling will immediately die if they lack capped cold resistance, but huge rewards for accomplishing this tremendous feat.

[b]Win Condition/Sense of Accomplishment[/b]: At the end of the day it's nice to complete a game. This game seems to drag on forever with no true purpose. A purpose doesn't have to be grandiose, but even something like unlocking improved aesthetics or additional customization for completing many objectives would be great.


TL;DR : This game is a good choice if you want a short demo of genetics, or a game for an infant child to play. The lack of many quintessential mechanisms of evolution, combined with the highly tedious chore of turn based collection take a huge chunk out of the enjoyment of what this game could be. $17 price point is high, I would suggest buying in the $9-$13 range.

I like this game. I don't mind if a game is less exciting, and more of a slow-paste, relaxing game. I can really enjoy those types of games. However, this game simply lacks depth. The story mode, which I was really excited about, is more like a basic-tutorial sandbox mode. So that was a little disappointing. Nice animation, but it doesn't add anything to the gameplay or story. 

The travel element is a nice way to make things more interesting, but it's unbalanced. After a few hours of playing I just ask myself "What's the point?". And if you travel to an island unprepared (because how can you know at your first try what kind of dangers you are going to face?) your tribe can be extinct really quickly and the hours you have put into your game are gone. There is no "load game" option and there is really not enough time to adapt your tribe to the new “dangers” of the island.

Don't get me wrong, I like this game. But there is still a lot of work to do and right now I don't think it deserves a "recommended" review, because I would recommend to wait and see if the developers are going to make the game more interesting and make a real story mode.

If a relaxing sandbox game with no real challenges and not much depth is all you are looking for, then I would say go for it. And if you don't mind putting hours into playing and then loose it all in a couple of minutes.

35211135.review:
Eine optisch ansprechende Survival of the Fittest Simulation. 

Der Spieler wird aufgefordert eine Tierherde zu gründen und diese durch Mutation und Selektion an ihre Umwelt anzupassen. Es steht dem Spieler dabei frei ob seine Tiere sich zu Jägern oder Sammlern entwickeln. Die Entwicklung vollzieht sich über verschiedene Generationen. Mit jeder neuen Generation geben die Eltern ihre Gene in zufälliger Kombination an die Folgegeneration weiter. Dabei ist es möglich einzelne Merkmale für die Mutation zu markieren um eine schnelle Anpassung an sich ändernde Umweltbedingungen zu ermöglichen.

Die Herde zieht innerhalb einer Inselwelt von Insel zu Insel. Jede neue Insel bietet andere Bedingungen und neue Herausvorderungen. Durch wiederholtes Ausführen von Aktionen wie nach Nahrung graben, Früchte sammeln, Schwimmen oder Fische fangen werden neue genetische Merkmale freigeschaltet, die eine optimalere Anpassung an die Gegebenheiten der Inseln ermöglichen.
Manche Merkmale wie zum Beispiel eine Resistenz gegen Gift können nur erlangt werden, wenn sich die Heerde in Gefahr begibt und giftige Planzen oder Tiere verzehrt. Andere Merkmale können erlangt werden, indem artverwandte herdenfremde Tiere als Freunde gewonnen und in die Herde integriert werden.

Da die Lebensdauer der Tiere begrenzt ist und durch Krankheiten, Parasiten und Umwelteinflüsse wie extreme Hitze oder Kälte zusätzlich verkürzt wird, wird ein natürlicher Lebenskreislauf über mehrere Generationen simuliert.

Die Spieloberfläche ist leicht zu verstehen und intuitiv gut bedienbar. Der Zufall spielt eine große Rolle und erlaubt verschiedene Spielansätze. Deshalb hat das Spiel sowohl für den hobby Zoologen als auch den Optimierer einiges zu bieten. 

Ich empfehle es für alle Alterklassen, die fähig sind sich liebevoll und sorgsam um ein Haustier zu kümmern ;-)

35191683.review:
As a game lover and a biology lover this game has two places in my heart. One place is that it's a generally fun casual game, the other place is that I kind of went in expecting an evolution simulator and was a bit disapointed. So here's my review from both ends:

[h1] As a game: [/h1]
+Fun to play
+I like planning a perfect strain of these guys to go hide out and interbreed start a master race of rabbit things
+Pretty to look at 
+Nice music 
+I grow attached to these guys and then they die on me but I can't hold a funeral or eat their rotting corpse. 

-Could use a lot more variety with genes and islands.
-There's a tutorial but doesn't really go into the nitty-gritty of breeding and evolving, which is is aggravating because that's the reason I picked up this game
-Islands don't make any sense because you can just keep hopping until you find a new one you like, there's no real pressure to stay on an island that you don't like
-Maybe I need to get further into the game, but there doesn't seem to be too many predators and when there are combat is basically chase someone and click to attack 

[h1] The Biology[/h1]
+Heard that the Dev wanted to study biology or game design. Happy they kind of got to do both. 
+Holy fuck. Breeding 10000x better than Spore's dig-up-genes-and-use-them-whenever-you-want system
+Overall pretty good model of how basic genetics works (half genes from mom, half from dad, one is expressed, etc.) 
   Nothing like epigenetics, or codominant traits, but I wouldn't expect that from a AAA team

-Biggest complaint about the game is the fact that food is communal. Eliminates like half the selective pressures on the creatures. I'd really love to see personal food stocks implimented for each animal, that way you actually can weed out the weak quickly. 
-Not really a negativve but I'd love to see more gene variety. I know the game just came out, but it'd be cool to see a clear divergence between different tribes or subspecies. Hell speciation would be awesome to see. 


Overall fun game, I think it could use some more polishing, but if you're like me and love biology, genetics, and/or evolution or just want a fun game to play I'd say this is well worth the price.

35180789.review:
Niche is one of those unique games that don't succeed very often due to being very different from what you usually see on the market. It looks and feels very much like a board game at times, with as much strategy involved as you feel like having. It can be a casual breeding game or an intense battle for survival (if you decide to play on one of the more difficult islands), all depending on how deeply/seriously you want to get into it. 
The game is basically about keeping your family of creatures alive and well by helping them get food, protect themselves from predators and survive the various natural hazards of their environment, mostly by breeding for different features and genes that allow you to shape your creatures any way you like. The gameworld consists of "islands" that have different bioms (savannah, jungle, mountain, grassland, etc.). Your animals can travel to different islands if you wish, but keep in mind that each one has its own challenges based on its bioms. 
[spoiler]At the moment Savannah tops my list as the most difficult island to thrive on due to many predators and natural hazards.[/spoiler]
The game offers two types of play. You can play the Story mode which starts you off with a creature named Adam and includes a simple tutorial that helps you get started (good for beginners). After the tutorial you are free to play as you like. The other option is the Sandbox mode which allows you to set your own difficulty from the get-go by letting you choose any island you want to start on (good for advance players). 
You start off with two creatures and with them create a tribe which you will expand with further breeding. Periodically you will encounter stray creatures which you can invite into your clan, thus expanding the gene pool. 
Movement is turn based. Each creature has three moves per game day (when adults) and two or one move when they are babies. You can use their free moves to forage for food, breed, explore (by moving from tile to tile), and do some other actions/interactions. When you have used up all the moves of all the animals you can end the day to progress to the next one/trigger aging, giving birth to cubs etc. 
You can collect different types of food like berries, digging up roots, cracking nuts, or hunting for rabbits, moles, fish, etc., or even collect meat from enemies that you defeat. Each creature will consume food at the end of the day. If you lack the food, they will starve and slowly die with each passing turn.
The core of the game is breeding for specific genes. There are many genes available, and hidden ones that you unlock by inviting animals with given genes into your tribes, or by performing actions (for example, trying to dig up roots will eventually unlock/strengthen your digging paw gene). Combine animals with traits you like to produce animals with desired characteristics while avoiding defects, doubled up immunity etc. By having different physical characteristics, some creatures will be better for hunting, defending, fishing, digging, foraging, etc. For more difficult bioms you might need certain creature features to help you survive. There is also the ability to mutate genes into your creatures if you wish and much more. The possibilities are endless and each time you breed, you will get a slightly different creature. 
The game is well done, works very well (though it's not very graphic intensive), doesn't have that many bugs/glitches, so kudos to the dev team. There are also planned expansions for the game if they get enough funding through sales here on Steam. 
All in all, the game is a fantastic choice for anyone interested in genetics, biology, strategy, survival, etc. There is so much more I could talk about here, but Steam has its limits. It's great to play with kids and other family members as it does a very good job of teaching the basics of genetics. I couldn't recommended it enough.

35179722.review:
So, like, I haven't played very far into Niche, but I feel like I have a pretty good handle on how the mechanics work in terms of how they're going to be read by the average gamer.

Basically, I think there's two ways you can look at the game.  You can look at it as a game that you play to achieve a specific goal, and you can look at it as a sandbox simulation of genetics.  As such, I've split my review into two parts, based on which perspective you're going for.

There's also a five-second TL;DR at the bottom if you REALLY want it, but I advise looking over the details before deciding on a purchase.

--------------------------

[b][u]AS A GAME:[/u][/b]

If you ask me to pick what this game's [i]primary[/i] genre is, it's definitely survival.  There is no goal in this game save surviving as long as possible, which is accomplished by wandering the wilds looking for food and fighting or avoiding hostile creatures.  Death not only comes easily, it is inevitable, since every creature has its own designated time-based lifespan which is visible on their HUD.  You have to be okay with dying.

However, in addition to survival, there's a fairly strong presence of the strategy genre here as well, and it's the main genre informing the game mechanics that make this game different from other survival games.  First, it's turn-based--time won't pass until you tell it to, so no quick reactions are required, you can take your time planning.  To compensate, though, resources deplete much more quickly than most survival games in terms of how long it takes your characters to actually reach resources.  So you don't have to plan quickly, but you do have to plan WELL.

The other new mechanic introduced by the strategy aspect is that you're controlling an entire tribe of creatures rather than just a single creature.  The more creatures you have, the more you can accomplish in any given day.  This allows you to multitask.  The idea is that you can have a few creatures focused on gathering resources to outpace/match the rate that those resources are being depleted by the tribe as a whole, and if you can accomplish that, then you're free to send a spare creature or two to go exploring or doing something else entirely.  This is why resources deplete as quickly as they do, and it's why the game can get away with allowing creatures to die of old age--your goal isn't the survival of any individual creature, it's to keep a family going for as many generations as you can.

I feel like the game's also a bit like a roguelike in the sense that there is no way you can prepare for every situation the first time you play the game.  Other reviews have mentioned that the tutorial doesn't really explain very much, but I feel like that's intentional--part of the fun in roguelikes is dying in new and unexpected ways, so you know to plan for that your next time through, which allows you to last long enough to see a new enemy and die in ANOTHER new way you didn't expect.  Gradually, you organically develop your own personal strategies to account for all the different possible ways you can die.  You do it on your own, not because the game explained how to do it.

--------------------------

[b][u]AS A SANDBOX:[/u][/b]

If you are totally okay with your creatures dying, then technically this game doesn't have any specific goals at all, at which point the "genetics" aspect becomes the central focus of the game.  Congratulations, you now have an edutainment title on your hands!

Except it's not really an edutainment title, because it's not meant to be 1-for-1 accurate to how genetics work in real life.  It's more meant to provide a big-picture simulation of how genetics influences survival, reproduction, and consequently evolution and/or death in real-world environments.  The genetics in this game are more about phenotypes than genotypes--and if you understood that statement without needing to look up the words, you probably understand genetics well enough that the way they work in the game will make sense to you.

If you DON'T know what genotypes are, then too bad, because the other reason this game isn't really an edutainment title is because it doesn't actually EXPLAIN any of this stuff to you.  If you're planning on interfacing with the genetics in this game in any meaningful way, you will need to come into this game with your own knowledge of certain concepts related to genetics, including (but perhaps not limited to):

1. How inheritance works
2. How mutations work
3. The difference between dominant and recessive genes
4. Why males have only one of a certain gene and females have two

If you don't know/care about any of these concepts, that's okay, you can probably still play this game as well as anyone else.  The reason for this is because, like in real life, you don't really have a whole lot of [i]control[/i] over what the genetic makeup of your tribe is.  You can lean in certain directions, but ultimately you're limited to what's available.  The most effective way to introduce new genes to the pool is to look for creatures to mate with outside of your own tribe, and sometimes you have to take what you can get.  Otherwise, you're limited to sporadic (semi-controlled) mutations and inbreeding--which is a totally viable option if you don't mind halving your creatures' lifespans through autoimmune deficiencies.

All this is why I think the game doesn't totally work as a sandbox, though, because the game is too [i]restricted[/i] to be a sandbox.  In something like the Sims, you have total control over what your character looks like, what their house looks like, who their parents, are, etc.  There is currently no game mode in Niche that lets you do that, and as far as I know, they're not planning to introduce one.  So there's no REAL way to play around and experiment to see the direct correlation between genetics and body makeup.  Instead, you're limited to the other half of the Sims, which poking around to get food, getting bored, and then goading your characters into dying in a variety of creative and horrible ways.

--------------------------

TL;DR: You may like this game if you are:

1. A gamer interested in survival and/or strategy games, and want to see a game that blends the two genres together.
2. A science-oriented person who already knows basically how genetics work, but wants to see how it practically functions and influences survival in nature.

Ideally, both of the above will apply to you to some extent.  If neither of these things appeals to you, you should probably give the game a pass.

35179635.review:
This game impressed the hell out of me. Though I'll admit, looking at the screenshots I was a little put off since it looks a bit cartoony. So pleased I decided to pull the trigger and buy it! There's actually a real challenge to trying to balance survival and continuation of your species with "good" genes. 

The concept is rather simple on the surface: Reproduce and attempt to get the best genetic combinations possible through breeding without producing sickly offspring (deformed, inadaquate immune systems, etc) all while trying to find enough food to keep the herd going. There is definitely a taste of Spore involved, but unlike Spore where you do all the creating, Niche is almost like playing a cute virtual game of Gregor Mendel where instead of peas you're breeding (possibly) deadly creatures. Taking a page from Don't Starve, you do keep some of your genetic bloodline if your herd dies and you have to start over which allows you to have a bit of a headstart on subsequent playthroughs. Additionally, Each playthrough islands are precedurally generated so things stay interesting. Don't expect your first herd to survive forever.

Most importantly, watch out for derpy rogue guys perpetuating sexually aggressive culture (Steam censors the R word). It's a thing. It'll mess up your bloodlines and possibly your game if you let the offspring survive... For such a cute game on the surface, there's some REALLY messed up choices to be made. 

Overall, this game has A LOT of replayability!

35157777.review:
This is kind of a sad negative review. I have been following the game for a while and was waiting on it exiting EA to get the full experience. After the long wait, I was pretty disappointed. The tutorial was abyssmal, you learn nothing but the absolute basics, it doesn't teach you what any icons mean or do, it doesn't teach you how to manipulate the genes besides "Mate these two". 

You have an entire dna helix representing the presumably predisposed genes the animal has but with no background on what they mean or how to manipulate them, short of seeing that you are likely to have offspring with bad or slightly less bad eyesight/hearing/smell/strength/etc and if its +0, +1, or +2 to an attribute.

Ultimately the gene choices mean nothing, they make VERY little impact on the actual game. It is incredibly slow paced and boring. You can decide to fight, forrage etc. but, they are all literally the same. Wanna be warriors? Try to manipulate genes to give you attack power, click on an enemy and that's it. Forrage? Exact same thing, find a nut/berry bush/clam/etc. click on the icon and that's it. 

Take the term strategy VERY lightly, as there is very little. You just blindly wander through a map looking for other npcs to mate or kill and that's about it. There is no strategy to speak of, find someone that you will get killed by, run away. Find something you can kill but, can't offer to join your tribe, kill it. The game lacks depth.

One of the very interesting ideas the game put forth was senses, you can choose to perceive your surroundings using sight, hearing, and smell. They allow you too "see" different things. Sight will let you see things like acorns on the ground, smell and hearing let you see other animals in the bushes, and so on. The downside however, the is virtually no reason to use sight, tall grass renders it pretty useless and it's way easier to just use sound or hearing as not only does it let you "see" through things like grass, it by default gives you a larger range to "see". Which is unfortunate as the game is actually quite nice to look at when you can see the vibrant colors and details, all of which you miss in the superior hearing/smelling modes.

There are not a lot of genetic mutations to unlock, and a vast majority of them are strictly cosmetic and add nothing to the game.

This could have been a much better and deeper game and might very well be with updates but, as it stands now fully released with very little depth, an atrocious tutorial for a game with very unobvious mechanics, and generally boring gameplay I cannot recommend buying this game.

Take the vast amount of positive reviews with a grain of salt, as the majority of them are staunch Niche supporters and have been playing well into EA and are pretty biased. It won't break the bank to buy, or try by any means but, there are much better games to shell your money out for.

35153573.review:
I got Niche a year or two ago, and it's been one of my favorite games since. It's a great turn-based strategy game and, although it may not be everyone's cup of tea, I recommend buying it. 

 Pros:

1: You can replay it as much as you want without getting bored with the game. Every time you start a new game, it's different. You can give your creatures personalities and a story, unlock achievements (some of them are really hard, for those of you looking for a challenge!!), get the weirdest genes possible, or you can see how long you can survive in a world that is constantly changing. 

2: It has an amazing, supportive, and extremely helpful community. Not only that, but the developers are incredibly helpful and invested in what their community has to say: It really is a wonderful thing to see developers working with their community to improve the game. 

3: There are tons of genes you can unlock for your creatures! From prehistoric genes to underwater breathing abilities, there's a type of animal for every person waiting to be created. (you can even make hybrids!) 

4: There are countless islands of varying difficulties and sizes to explore, and hidden creatures in them waiting to be invited into your pack. Once you start a game in one of the islands, you can still move to another island with travel ports. (but be warned!! if you make creatures suited for the snow and go to a savanna, chances are you won't last very long. thankfully, the ports have different colors and designs so you can tell which one you're about to go to.) 

5: There's a sandbox mode and a storymode, both of which have tons to explore. In sandbox mode, you can choose which island you want to start off on and you have randomized creatures. In storymode, you start with Adam, who is lost and looking to come back to his old home. Storymode is recommended for new players because it's also the tutorial. I would go into greater detail, but then it'd spoil the story for you, and I'm not going to do that. ;) 

Cons:

1: There are very short lifespans. While the short lifespans (only around 20 in game turns) provide more of a challenge and can be exciting, it also makes it harder to get attached to certain creatures before they die. You can still get attached (and then it's heartbreaking when they die!!) but you don't miss the creature as much when you lose them as you might if you had more time with them. 

2: At the beginning of each game, you have two starter creatures: One male and one female. (used to be called Adam and Eve but now have randomly generated names.) When you start a game, you have to cross your fingers because you have no idea how your starters will be. They could have extremely bad genetics, or incredibly good ones. It's all about luck, and I only consider it a con because it can create an unexpected challenge. 



All in all, I think it's a great game and recommend it to anyone who likes strategy, genetics, and cute animals.

I originally backed this game during the kickstarter.
First id just like to say that im happy with the dev team as they got most what they promised out the door quite fast and the few things that didnt come with the release are promised to come with updates shortly after (wings).

If you like survival games and dont mind turnbased stuff then your going to like this game even if you dont get it on sale.
So im not going to go into all the possitive stuff, im just going to outline what could be better.

Tutorial:
The game sugests you play the story mode about adam and eve so you learn the concept of the game.
However given the unique style of survival turnbased game it is, there really needs to be a proper tutorial system and not a simple hint system.

i would advice something like big moving arrows pointing to this "adam" and teaching you basic gameplay mechanics like how to get food, mate, nest, and just survive.
Instead the game gives you a couple hints telling you how to move and move the camera and that you can interact with things like berry bushes or grass, then it tells you to move off the island. 
But these are just all hints and the player can do ther own thing or not even read them. I was actually reading one and it changed on me and i was lost thinking how do i do that.

Given the choice to stop/skip parts or all of the tutorial and that you always treat the player as generally knowing nothing but with respect. The player will have a much better experience playing your game than with a rushed tutorial that doesnt explain the gameplay properly.

Niche is alright.

35137050.review:
Now, I backed this game on Kickstarter in early 2016, and have been playing some form of it since then, from a rough early access test version made available before it hit Steam all the way up to it's official release today (Sept. 21, 2017). 
Over the course of that I watched the game and community as a whole grow. The developers have created an amazingly inclusive community. They've demonstrated in multiple ways their willingness to cater to their players and their sincerity in accomplishing their promises to the best of their abilities.

In regards to the gameplay itself: personally, I adore it. The general breakdown of the game is that you start with two randomly generated adorable little Nichelings on a small island with very few dangers and plenty of food. 
You breed your founders to grow your group, and sometimes find random wanderers to join you. Meanwhile you're deciding which members to breed together, what kind of nose is the best (or the cutest) what kind of feet you want, what kind of tail, what color, what pattern.
Do you want them to crack nuts? Do you want them to catch fish? Or do you want it to be so beefy they can smash rocks? 
Then you eventually move on to another island to try and adapt and survive there, constantly evolving to new enviorments. 

The freedom you have in creating a genetically unique and intricate tribe is so much fun.  
(Currently my group of little dudes are rainbow colored with skunk tails and snake fangs)

All that being said, the game is quite slow-paced and intricate, with a considerable learning curve on the UI. 
There's a good tutorial storymode available though, and it's pretty efficient for how much information you're given, and how much control you have over your group's genetics. 

Overall, I highly recommend this game ^.^

35135360.review:
This game obviously has a lot of promise, so please take this as a very tentative "thumbs down". The game just feels too.. small, or bare-boned at the moment to be a full release at 17$.

[b]First Impressions:[/b]
When you start a new game, you have either the option of playing "story" or "sandbox" mode. I highly recommend playing story mode if you are new to the game, because it's actually more of a tutorial than a story mode (almost should be labeled "tutorial" instead of "story), which leaves sandbox mode as the main focus of the game. The tutorial does seem fairly lacking in explaining many of the game functions as well, which I believe should be addressed at some point. An example of this is how to pass on dominant/recessive genes, or how to use mutations, I have not seen anywhere in-game where this is explained.

The sandbox mode allows you to choose from among a fairly large amount of maps, which is great. However, it does not give you an option to pre-set any of your starting creature attributes, which are instead decided through sheer RNG (randomly). This feels like a HUGE feature to be left out. You can just restart over and over until you get a specific starting attribute that you were hoping for (I.E. horns, digging claw, etc.). It would also be great if there were at least 1-2 more body types to choose between, maybe something bipedal, or the option to begin in the sea and evolve legs eventually. Something to hope for in the future, I suppose.

Another feature that I feel should have been included is a difficulty setting for younger, or less experienced players. Something requiring less food per turn, less predators or longer creature life. Any custom settings at all would have been nice, in fact. I realize that the map you choose does this to some degree, but it's not enough at the moment.

The sight/smell/hearing toggle is a great concept, but I find that there is very little practical use for sight in general due to the tall grass that is prevalent on every map. This leaves me playing the game in black and white, which detracts from it to a degree. I wish that the "senses" could have been implemented in a way that caused items or creatures detected by scent or hearing to just appear in a color that signified what sense it was detected with. For example, items detected by scent could show with a yellow silhouette, hearing could be blue. Something to that effect, rather than a full toggle.

Those are my only complaints about the game currently. I do not plan to refund it, as I can see Niche becoming a truly great game with several updates. The developers have been responsive and friendly in the forums and when replying to reviews, and that gives me a lot of hope for the future of this game.

Question to devs - Why does attacking a rogue male with a female creature get her pregnant?

35126829.review:
I'm not an RTS player by any means, but Niche made a convert out of me. Not only is the game design sickeningly adorable (have you seen those twee faces??), but the fact that it's based on actual biological principles makes it a great game for players of any age. You have to figure out how to manage resources versus individual animals' aptitudes and protect them against bearenyas, rogue males, sickness, giant birds, and any number of obstacles I haven't encountered yet. Be forewarned, even though these are tiny digital creatures you do get a bit attached to them, so make sure you have someone or -thing nearby to snuggle in case of feels-mergencies (where you get the feels so bad you've gotta hug something), but to see generations thrive as they travel from island to island is so very worth it!

Much of the game can be figured out via trial and error, but there's a very helpful wiki on Fandom to get you by in tough spots. Much like Kerbal Space Program, it's definitely not the kind of game you'll be able to master in an afternoon, but once you get the feel for it, the possibilities are endless (and honestly, I'm glad it's so complex, because it's eminently replayable). If you're on the fence, definitely check out some Let's Play videos online, but if you like games that are both cute and savage, this is a winner. Looking forward to whatever Stray Fawn Studio does next!

35117649.review:
Niche looked like it was going to be a really fun game right up until I hit the tutorial and it became obvious how poorly designed the interface is.  

One step of the tutorial tells you to click the family tree button "in the lower left", but there are a lot of buttons in the lower left and most of them aren't labeled.  None of the stats are explained in the tutorial, nor is the mutation mechanic, the action count, or many of the other important features.  

It gets even worse once you leave the tutorial and puts you on an "easy" island.  I don't dislike hard games, I love a challenge.  But there's a difference between something being hard because it requires skill and something being hard because you can't win if the game decides to throw the wrong thing at you.  Here's the setup for this problem:  All of your animals have a limited lifespan and can take a maximum of three actions per day, two or even one if they're not fully grown.  Those actions include moving, collecting food, cutting grass, attacking things, mating, everything.  Each of your animals also require one unit of food every day which must be located and collected.  Movement actions are limited to one space at a time if there's tall grass in the way and almost every space starts off with tall grass.  That, in and of itself, was frustrating enough.  All three actions in a day would be spent cutting grass and moving to find food while the food meter slowly goes to zero.  And then just when you think you've got all your space cleared up for easy movement and your food sources located and you might actually be able to start playing the game, the grass starts growing back.  It doesn't even grow back in the order you removed it, it's as though every space has a percent chance of just spawning new grass every day.  If you do manage to secure enough food sources to keep your animals fed, some bigger creature shows up and starts systematically killing them off.  In my first game some huge black thing showed up and started attacking my animals one at a time and it took three days of all three animals attacking it with every action to kill it and by that time it had killed two of them and the last one was starving.  This is the easy island right out of the tutorial and it didn't get any better in subsequent games.

So no, I don't recommend anyone buy this game.  If it was in early access I could cut it some slack for not having its systems sorted out yet, but this is a full release which means someone had to look at this and say "Yup, that's what I want my game to be".  That's upsetting because this game looks like it has so much promise.  Revamp the tutorial and rethink the core systems and I would give it another chance, but the way it is I can't bring myself to start up another new file.

35113402.review:
First off congratualtions to the team on the official launch!

Secondly:

TLDR: A breeding game with a twist. This game is amazing. If your into survival games, if you like turn based games, if you love animals and like a challenge (especially when it comes to breeding a creature you like) this is the game for you.

I've only ot 12 hours on this account but I originally logged about 40 hours on my sisters before buying it myself. I think I started playing back on 0.3.0 and the game has come on leaps and bounds since then. I originally saw this game and knew I would love it just because of the art. Its such a cute game with amazing artwork that has inspired allot of beautiful fan art in return. I've also always loved games that involve breeding animals, it fascinates me and this game takes it that one step further by making genes that your survival depends on.

Cons: 
-If you don't like micro mangment your not going to like this game. You have to micro manage every move and action your creature makes. You have to choose specific genes you want to try and breed into your tribe for EVERY creature.

Pros (AKA why I love the game)
-If you like micro managment see above, I like micro managment, at the very least it dosnt bother me!
-With a diverse gene pool of colours, patterns, claws, eyes, horns and special ancient genes (plus many more) you end up with a diverse and intresting tribe of creatures. Its can be a fun challenge to try and breed a creature that can not only survive and thrive, but look exactly how you want.
-Challenging terrain makes for intresting game play as your forced to adapt to your enviroment. From growing gills to deal with water and posion fangs to help you harvest poisnous berries your forced to hunt for the perfect mate to join your tribe.
-The danger doesn't just lie in what is under your feet but what lurks around you. Rouge males with negative genes stalk you through the grass waiting for a lone female to stray from the tribe, leeches lurk at the water's edge waiting to grab onto a passing baby (or even worse a bird swooping down and grabbing your baby!) and the big bearyenas roam around. These threats force you to keep on your toes and depending on what genes you have in your tribe you can try to fight or run. A fun update before launch added the possibility of bearyena hybrids that can introduce important genes into your tribe and I hope to see more hybrids introduced in the future!

To sum it up it's a cute entertaining game. If your unsure watch some of the many youtube videos that are already out about previous releases. Its a challenge to survive which is a good thing.

35057634.review:
(WARNING RAMBLE)
I love niche, and I have had it for a while, so I thought I might write a review.
Niche is full of content, (with even more coming!), and you can mish-mash stuff however you want. There are two modes: sandbox and story. In story mode, you start with Adam losing his family and go on the quest to find them with his new mate, eve, whose descendants search for the fabled adam's island where Adam's family resides. You can go full or do-or-die in sandbox, facing harsh climates and deadly predators completely unprepared, or you can travel around the peaceful islands, experimenting with the random genes you received and telling story's. 

I have found that most (correct me if I am wrong)of the negative reviews on niche are made by people who have p,Syed under an hour, and they complain about the fact that the game seems "boring", "confusing", "repetitive", and that's true, at the start, but as you advance to new islands and survive, your tribe's story's become more complex and interesting. The only way for it to be boring is if a) you spend only 30 mins on it like most of the negative reviewers did and then just drop it, or you have no creativity at all.
 Niche allows you to build your own culture and traditions. You shape the feel of your world, choose the colors and landscapes.
The unlocking system for niche genes is quite clever, based on real genetics but a little more loosey goosey so you don't have to wait billions of generations like in real life. You can completely change the genetic make up of a tribe in 3 generations!
Although the island unlocking system in Storymode is a bit tedious, you can just switch to a Sandbox game and BOOM you are on the island you wanted to be on.
Niche is an overall great game!
My only critique: (take note these are minor things, not that important. I like to nit-pick :P)
is that there should be a creature creator that lets you see what combinations would look like and what they would do.
is that there should be more uses for digger paw
Is that fully-hybridized nichelings should have better movement, although it is true that it would be a little op. But still, I would like the movement to be at least 2, maybe even 3, but not one!
(This is only if you want more than 5 games or you want to play older versions but still have room to make new games on the other versions)Is that there should be a way to get the save file of a game without having to dig through your folders (and the folder it's in does not appear on some platforms) like maybe a small button on the screen next to your worlds that will open up the folder automatically.

Combined with the survival element it's challenging and interesting. It has possibilities for teaching how genetics work and even comparing it to how humans evolved.

The graphics have their own style and the Nichelings are just SO cute and make the cutest sounds.

There are tons of suggestions I have to make it even better, such as a tutorial (I've been playing it for a while so I know how it works but it seems a common theme that people don't "get" the game) or a versus multiplayer mode. Where tribes attack eachother and "claim" land. That's a big update though so it would most likely be an expansion if it were to happen.

I didn't recieve a key from the developer by the way - I bought the game because it was interesting and I don't regret it at all! I'm excited to see where they take it.

35015984.review:
Hey Pack,

hiermit möchte ich kurz ein paar Verbesserungsvorschläge sowie Lob und Dank an die Entwickler vermitteln. Aber kommen wir erstmal zum zweiten: Lob und Dank

Ich empfehle das Spiel auf jeden Fall. Ich mag es sehr gerne, da ich mich für Biologie und Genetik interessiere. Die Grafik ist hübsch und es ist liebevoll gestaltet (Die Tiere sind total knuffig 0.o). Mit dem neuen Update sehen die Inseln viel besser aus. Es gibt viele Eigenschaften, die man den Tieren anzüchten kann, die einem helfen in der Umgebung zurecht zu kommen und besser Nahrung zu finden. Auch das Tutorial mit der kleinen Geschichte hat mir sehr gefallen. Gut und realistisch ist auch, dass man versuchen kann Nüsse aufzuknacken, auch wenn die Fähigkeit Nüsse aufzuknacken nicht sehr ausgeprägt ist. Es gibt eine geringe Wahrscheinlichkeit, dass man es dennoch schafft. Es gibt noch viele andere Sachen die mir gefallen, aber das kürze ich einfach mal etwas ab.
Vielen Dank an die Entwickler. Ein "genetics survival game" hab ich mir ehrlich gesagt schon lange gewünscht. Es macht wirklich Spaß Auszuprobieren und später über den Stammbaum nachzuvollziehen welche Eigenschaft von wem vererbt wurde. Vielleicht geht es nur mir so, aber das ist besonders als Biologe interessant. Das Spiel wäre meiner Meinung auch gut, um Vererbung anderen beizubringen, da man die Vorgänge wirklich sehen kann. Super, dass dieses Projekt wirklich was geworden ist. Ich verfolge die Entwicklung seit der Alpha und muss sagen, dass es sich gut entwickelt hat. Hoffendlich folgen nach dem Release noch Verbesserungen und Updates, die das Spiel erweitern. Wie wäre es mit einer Campaign?

Nun zu den Verbesserungsvorschlägen:
Tut mir wirklich leid das zu sagen, aber es ist etwas falsch dargestellt. In dem Menü, wo die genetischen Eigenschaften eines Tieres gezeigt werden, wird eine DNA-Doppelhelix dargestellt. Dabei wird jede Eigenschaft in eine Base gesetzt. Ein Basepaar fungieren als Allele. Das stimmt fachlich wirklich nicht und wenn ihr es ändern könnt, bitte tut es. Informiert euch nochmal (ich möchte diesen Review kurz halten und erkläre deshalb nicht). Auch wenn es hübsch aussieht, vielleicht wäre eine Darstellung mit verschiedenen Chromosomenpaaren auch geeignet.

Das wäre es auch schon. Wenn mir noch was einfällt, schreibe ich es noch dazu. Viele Grüße, Rupa

I really wanted to like this game, because the concept behind it was so appealing to me. However, after playing it I cannot recommend it. The main problem is that you need to have a large tribe to maintain genetic diversity, but managing a large tribe quickly becomes a boring chorelike slog. 

Almost as important is that managing your creatures genes is the central mechanic of the game, but the genetic records of your tribe are on a seperate screen from where you order them to mate. 34971905.review:
This game is amazing.  When I was a little girl, I was fascinated with genetics and heredity.  I used to make up games where you could see the genes of imaginary creatures, then breed them and see how those genes were passed on to their children.  I fervently wished that someone would make that game for real.  20 years later, I got my wish. :) 

Niche is full of adorable creatures whose genes have a real impact on not only their appearance, but the ways they can interact with the world around them.  Your job is to take control of a tribe, helping them to explore and ensuring their survival as they move from island to island.  Each island has different challenges for the Nichelings to overcome, and the abilities they get from their genotypes will determine how well they can gather food and deal with predators in each environment.  

There are many, many different ways to survive, so you're not locked into keeping a specific set of genes.  Nichelings use real genetics (including mutations!) and you can use this to guide the direction of your tribe.  Will you breed a tribe of mighty hunters?  Efficient gatherers?  Or maybe you just want your Nichelings to have adorable tiger stripes?  It's up to you!  You can even ignore the mutation system entirely and see what nature gives you.  An individual Nicheling's lifespan is relatively short, so making sure there are children who can carry on the tribe's legacy is an important part of the game.  My favorite part is just watching how the tribe evolves over time and seeing all the changes and mutations that my choices have introduced.

If you have even a passing interest in genetics, cute creatures, and survival games, I highly recommend Niche.
