30082253.review:
Was für ein süßes Spiel! 
Ja das liest man öfters und unterstreicht auch meinen Eindruck von Niche. Nachdem ich schon lange nach einem Ersatz für Spore gesucht habe, könnte dieses Spiel vielleicht endlich die Antwort sein. 

Nur.. was ist Niche?

Nun Niche simuliert das komplexe Gefüge von Genetik und Vererbung. Wir beginnen auf einer Insel, umringt von Wasser. Um unser tierisches Nest, steht meterhohes Gras, eine Nahrungsquelle und mitten drin unser Tier-Pärchen. Ganz simpel zu Beginn müssen wir für Nahrung sorgen und in der Wildnis überleben. Welche Gefahren auf unsere süßen Tierchen lauern, können wir bis dahin noch nicht abschätzen. Was wir aber sehr wohl wissen ist, das wir dafür sorgen müssen, dass unsere tierische Rasse nicht ausstirbt. Also müssen wir für Nachwuchs sorgen und diesen auch bis er alt genug ist beschützen. Wie wir wissen, gibt es dominante und rezessive Gene, die im Spiel, bestimmten Eigenschaften zugeordnet sind und von denen wir, jederzeit, Einblick haben bei unseren erwachsenen Tieren. Am Anfang können wir also schon erahnen: Wir müssen viel Nachwuchs generieren, damit die genetische Vielfalt zunimmt und wir für die nächste Generation versuchen können, die besseren Eigenschaften, den nächsten Kindern weiterzugeben, damit diese noch überlebensfähiger werden. Mehr Nachwuchs bedeute aber wiederum auch, mehr Nahrungsbedarf und auf Nahrung können wir auf keinen Fall verzichten. Doch haben wir schlau unsere Tierchen verpaart, könnte der nächste Nachwuchs vielleicht viel effizienter Nahrung sammeln, als es die Eltern-Tiere noch konnten. Genauso handelt es sich um die Gefahren. Wilde Tiere können wir zu Anfang nur schwer bekämpfen. Zudem reduziert jede Verletzung die maximale Lebensspanne eines Tiers (und ja..auch in diesem Spiel sterben leider unsere Tierchen früher oder später) Doch auch hier, könnte uns das clevere Genetik-System helfen. Vielleicht schaffen wir es, eine genetische Eigenschaft, unseren Tierchen zu vererben, damit die nächste Generation effizienter gegen wilde Tiere kämpfen kann. Z.b. hat unser Nachwuchs zu Beginn ein Horn, das in der nächsten Generation voll ausgeprägt ist. Vielleicht haben sie sogar schon ein zweites? Viele genetische Kombinationen sind möglich und helfen unseren Tierchen, sich der Umwelt anzupassen. So ist es auch möglich, dass unsere Tierchen evolutionär, größer oder kleiner werden, was alles wiederum Vor und Nachteile hat. Vielleicht werden sie besser schwimmen können? So können auch Fell und Fellmuster vererbt werden oder durch genetische Mutation, entstehen ganz neue Kombinationen. Viele körperliche Elemente spielen eine Rolle. 

Wie im echten Leben, in denen sich über tausende Jahren Tiere und auch wir Menschen, uns evolutionär angepasst haben auf unsere Umwelt, so geschieht dies auch in diesem Spiel. Im Gegensatz zu Spore, haben wir nicht die volle Kontrolle, welche Eigenschaften oder Körperteile unsere Tierchen bekommen, sondern müssen erst das System der Genetik verstehen, um einen gewissen Einfluss darauf zu haben. Einen Baukasten findet man hier nicht. Wir können innerhalb einer Generation darauf hinarbeiten, wie die Nachfahren unserer Tierchen werden könnten. Das alles macht das ganze extrem reizvoll und hat einen hohen Wiederspielwert.

Unsere Tierchen sind auch nicht gezwungen, auf der Insel zu bleiben. Es besteht die Möglichkeit, mit unserer Meute auch ein neues Gebiet zu suchen, um neue Ortschaften zu entdecken. Damit erweitert sich der Spielumfang nochmal deutlich.

Zu der Grafik kann man als erstes sagen: Wie süß sind diese Wesen gestaltet? Ich muss sagen, seit Ori and the blind forest, haben ich kein süßer gestaltetes Wesen gesehen. Sehr liebevoll detailliert und was mir sehr gut gefällt, sind die Tierchen, die den Kopf immer mit dem Mauszeiger bewegen. 
Die Umgebung ist auch recht hübsch gestaltet aber mehr zweckmäßig. Da könnte man mehr Details und Lebendigkeit einbauen. Der Stil allgemein ist mehr Comichaft Allerdings. nicht zu bunt, sondern auch etwas ernster. Das Spiel ist nun mal auch nicht ganz so fröhlich, wie es den Anschein hat. Es beschäftigt sich mit dem leben aber auch mit dem Tod und das auf einer doch rationalen Art und weiße aber wer behauptete auch, das die Natur immer fröhlich ist und keine Schattenseite hat?

Untermalt wird das Ganze, mit der immerzu laufenden, ruhigen aber wie ich finde auch irgendwie traurig, klingenden Melodie. Eine entspannte Melodie, die mich aber auch auf eine gewisse Art und weiße berührt und mich irgendwie einach traurig stimmen lässt. Vielleicht aus der Tatsache heraus, das meine süßen Tierchen irgendwann auch sterben werden und deren Nachwuchs ebenfalls. Das nicht für ewig bleibt. Es ist schwer zu beschreiben. Vielleicht um das Ganze ein bisschen..wirklich nur ein bisschen, aufzulockern, wäre eine Idee, noch andere Melodiestücke einzubauen, die auch ein wenig fröhlicher klingen. Das ist aber auch ein ganz eigener persönlicher Wunsch und fällt nicht in meine allgemeine Kritikliste.

Das Interface ist nett aber sehr zweckmäßig und wirkt noch unausgereift. Es ist schwer sich trotz Hilfen am Anfang zurechtzufinden. Tooltipps fehlen und die Symbole erklären sich auch nicht gleich von selbst. Da muss man auf jedenfalls noch was machen.
Auch ein deutlich umfangreicheres Tutorial ist Pflicht, da das Thema der Genetik, viel zu komplex ist, um es mit einfachen Bildchen zu erklären.

Zusammenfassung: 
Niche - a genetics survival game ist ein sehr schönes, liebevoll gestaltetes Spiel, das sehr gut, wie ich finde, das System der Genetik auch wiedergibt. Eine sehr gute Simulation der Evolution und der eigentlichen Natur in einer rationalen Art und weiße. Leben entsteht und passt sich der Umwelt an, in dem die dafür nötigen Eigenschaften, durch Vererbung, den Nachkommen weitergegeben werden. Und leben vergeht. Die alte Generation, die naturgemäß ausgedient hat.  Ein nie endender Prozess. Der Kreislauf des Lebens. Dieses Spiel simuliert die Natur, so wie sie ist, gepaart aber mit auflockernden Comicstil, süßen Tierchen, schöner Umgebung und mit Survival-Elementen. 
Das Interface und Tutorial, sind gefühlt die größten Baustellen und damit auch für mich die größten Kritikpunkte, die aber dem Early Acces Status, höchst wahrscheinlich zu verschulden sind und damit absolut verschmerzbar. 
Die Updates scheinen etwas zu brachen, verändern aber das Spiel recht umfangreich. 
Noch ein wunsch, wäre natürlich mehr content, wenn es irgendwie in das Spiele-Schema passen würde.

Schlussendlich zeigt aber Niche sehr gut, was ewiges Leben wirklich bedeutet. Das ein Teil unseren Eltern und deren Eltern aber auch ein Teil von uns, in unseren Kindern und deren Kindern, immer weiter existieren wird. Somit sind wir alle, auf eine anderen natürlichen weiße, unsterblich.

Edit 22.02.2017
Tja wie es der Zufall so will, kam praktisch am gleichen Tag meiner Review, das versprochene Februar Update. Neue Landschaft (Dschungel) und Umstrukturierung des Interface. Das geht auf jedenfall in die richtige Richtung. Auch wird ein umfangreicheres Tutorial versprochen. Ebenfalls positiv! Man kann nun auch Nester selber bauen. Mein lieblings Feature ist aber ganz klar, die Möglichkeit, zwischen  visueller, akustischer ud olfaktorischer (Geruchsinn) wahrnehmung hin und her zu wechseln um Nahrungsquellen und gefahren von weiter weg wahrzunehmen. Ein tolles Update. Bitte weiter so!

Edit: 16.05.2017
Und wieder ein neuer Patch und extrem erfreulich finde ich, dass es das Spiel nun auch auf deutsch gibt! Spitze! 
Zudem gibt es nun ein Temparatur-Feature mit passenden resistenzen und überarbeitete Inseln. Gefällt mir sehr gut. Weiter so!

29451998.review:
This game is extremely fun and informative. Niche is a genetics manager game- where you must manage your tribe's food, amount of nesting material you have to be able to have children, and your population as well as their genes. 

You must learn to balance out food for each tribe members. This can be a rough task at first, but as you pla the game more, you will realize how simple it is to get food, and how abundant the food in Niche really can be. Depending on your tribe's genetics, you may be able to quickly gain food by fishing, collecting berries, and collecting meat from crabs, rabbits, and other prey.

You must learn to gather nesting material or find a nest already placed on your island. Nests can be quite abundant as well, but it is nice having a nest you built yourself, because you can choose it's location. It can be placed next to a large amount of food. If you pick a pre-built nest it can be rough starting out depending on how close you are to your food sources. Building nests costs nesting material, and you get this from grass.

Like every ecosystem, there are predators. Depending on which habitat you choose to reside in, you will have different predators. These predators will easily kill you, unless you have the proper genetics to fend for yourself. There are many different genes you can use to protect yourself. All of these look different, and have different stats. The stronger genes you choose, the easier it will be to defend yourself.

These genes come from breeding your creatures together. Just like in the wild, the strongest nichelings will survive. If they are sickly, they will die quickly.

This game is a very relaxing game, and is playable for hours. Great game, and a simple way to teach adults and children how genetics work.

29132376.review:
Even in Early Access form, Niche is a solid game. The graphics even on the lower settings run my computer pretty hot, so it's probably not fully optimised yet, but even without all the features  fully implemented, the mechanics of the game are so well put in place that it's still really fun. There's a lot of potential, here, and I am looking forward to the next updates! 

There isn't really a tutorial, but it's intuitive enough that it almost doesn't need one. The only real things I would recommend would be to allow the player to be able to select the individual creatures through the family tree, or be able to mark them somehow. (Basically I keep planning out breeding schedules and then forgetting who I was going to breed with who...)

A slight warning for sexual abuse victims, however, there is a mechanic that could be triggering, which involves an unknown 'horny male' randomly appearing and mating with females in your population. The idea behind the mechanic is a good one - introducing unwanted or unknown genes into the gene pool, or adding variability while it wasn't there - but the suddeness of the implementation can be startling and sometimes unsettling.

29110454.review:
(I decided to remake this, it's been a year since I've edited it. Also I'm gonna do a new pro-con format inspired by a shelter 2 review. Forgot the user but you can find them)
Edit: hours spent on splatoon 2: 140+

So many of you have probably seen Seri's gameplay of Niche (including me, I'm guilty) and decided to give it a go. You don't even need to read this, you can tell I enjoyed this by looking at how many hours I spent on it... which strangely beated how much I spent on Splatoon 2, even though I enjoy that more than Niche... but I'm getting off topic.

Brief summary before I get into this: Niche is a genetics survival-and-strategy game. You can make your tribe desert nomads, exclusive berry-pickers, or just mess around in the console until you get the genetics you want. In my experiences, if you really want a sucessful tribe, stay on an island you're happy on (with lots of food) and DON'T move elsewhere. 

Since this is a new format, let's answer some questions... 

[b] Should I buy this?  [/b]
X No! 
X No, even if there is a sale!
✓ Yes, if there is a sale!
X Yes!

Let's just say the obvious: this game is NOT cheap. As of writing this, it is currently 18.99 USD. If the developers ever decide to release a sale, then that's the only time that I recommend buying it. 

[b] What are the graphics like? [/b]
X Looks like a cheap iPhone app!
X Low-Quality
✓ Okay
X Good-Quality
X IT'S SO GOOD MY EYES ARE CRYING TEARS OF BEAUTY!

I feel like this is a good time to address something; do NOT play this if you have a crappy computer. I have one, and this game lags HARD, even on the lowest possible settings. 

[b] What about gameplay? [/b]
X TERRIBLE!
✓ At least it's playable!
X Okay
X Good
X BEST GAMEPLAY EVER!

The gameplay is kinda sucky, but fairly simple. Only way you control your creatures: your mouse. No external costs (like controllers) are needed, you just need a mouse! And once you figure out a strategy, it becomes SUPER easy.

[b] Okay... story-mode? If there is any? [/b]
X Terrible and underwritten! (or there is none)
✓ Underwritten, but I can still understand what's happening.
X Okay
X Good
X MY GOD IT'S THE BEST STORY!

Let me get this straight: story mode is for NEW players. It's basically like assistance mode in Super Mario Odyssey, but a bit more vague. Even though the opening animation for it is gorgeous [strike] and better than I could ever do, [/strike] it doesn't contribute much to the story later, except when you find your way back [spoiler] to Adam's tribe. [/spoiler] Maybe when going to new islands, the tribe can get visions of [spoiler] the history of Adam's tribe? [/spoiler]

[b] Final and most important question: memes? [/b]
X NO MEMES!
✓ Memes, but not relevant.
X MEMES!

There is ONE in-game meme (otherwise I accidentally spawned the other,) and it's the title of a gene called 'derp snout.' Heh heh... these are times like this I missed 'spit-snout'

Overall, should you buy this game? If you are getting into genetics, like animals, or just want to play it because Seri played it, buy it! No one's stopping you. Otherwise, you're going to get bored fairly quickly.

28880349.review:
Niche belongs to a genre I rarely play, and if I play, then not for long. 
I'm not generally a patient person, and I like to have a goal to work to get to. 

I found this game randomly on youtube, and absolutely fell inlove with it. From the artstyle, to the gamestyle, to the way every move kind of mattered. I loved the idea of being able to breed my own animals and shape them in any way and form I wanted to - And with every update, the possibilities get bigger and better.

This isn't the game for you, if you need specific goals and achievements - At least not in its present form. However, it's very peaceful, it's engaging and with the ability to name your creatures, you can now bond further with them. Coming up with elaborate stories, personalities, etc. for each of them is a fun little pasttime. There's also always the chance of a mutation popping up at random. With some work though, you can completely costumize your creatures. I've become quite addicted to that.

With Early-Access games I never expect too much, because I know how much they can change. I've been so pleasantly surprised by this game however, that it's prompted me to write my first review. 

Another big thumbs up goes to the developers. I brought the game, and only recently became part of the Facebook Group that's devoted to talk about the game, report bugs quick and easily and share the enthusiasm of the game. The developers of the game is active in the group as well, and takes suggestions and engages with the core-group of the game. They also provide quick and effecient support, and they appear incredibly friendly and invested in making the game the best it possibly can be.

I'd recommend (And already have) to everyone with a little bit of patience. It's very rewarding and the artstyle is so, so beautiful. (Even.. The cracker jaw... And gills... And spit-snout.. Ehem.)

Educational... kind of.

Helpful and active devolopment team

Cons:

A bit repetitive, you are going to be doing A LOT of berry picking. and if you plan on playing the game for more than 30 minutes at a time it can get boring.

Confusing family tree and not easy enough to differentiate your animals

And... a bit lacking in content so far.


Do I recommend this game to players who just want to get in and start playing? No. 
But if your willing to stick with the game and wait till full release. Then by all means, get it. You will be supporting the devolment team. And its not like the game is horrible as it is right now, but it just has a few things that could be improved upon, and I am sure they will.

28807703.review:
Niche was an unexpectadly addictive game for me. I bought it on a whim a while back when seeing a few YouTube videos on it, and was drawn in by its interesting take on genetics, and the endless possibilities on offer in terms of creating creatures, and helping them survive despite difficulties in the environment. 

It is a challenging game if you really want to strategise and create the 'perfect' creature genetically, but can also be relaxing if you focus less on the details and more on the aspect of survival, and exploring the islands on offer. You can really choose your playing style, and if you wish, you can create your own challenges since it's so open. This makes it perfect as, kind of, an accidental role-playing game, if you wish to get attached to your creatures, which you will.

You watch them grow, you watch them breed, you watch them protect, you watch them die, and the generations go on and on, at a fairly fast-paced speed; which I love.

All in all, I play this game for its awesome art style and relaxing nature, but also so I can use strategy to manipulate the genetics, and really get that feeling of satisfaction when I finally create the perfect creature and survive the more difficult islands.

It's so challenging at times, that the satisfaction is ever-more rewarding! Definitely a tricky game to conquer, but well worth the buy!

I watched a youtuber play this after seeing it on Steam and taking an interest. It's exactly my kind of game, it's fun, it's bright and colourful, and it really makes you think about every move you have to make. Everything you do costs you food. Sometimes getting to food costs you food!

I can't wait until it's out of early access. The game doesn't currently have a family tree and you don't want to inbreed, so if you're as dedicated as me you're going to need a lot of paper and colours.

I seriously got invested. My boyfriend came home to me sat on the floor (my desk wasn't big enough) while I was surrounded in a huge family tree and notes, all colour coded into males, females, dead, blind, unrelated/new. It's one of those games you will invest hours of energy in.

I've never been able to get beyond a few squares into the second island. If you want a challenge by all means travel, but if you want to enjoy the game just live peacefully on the first island and occasionally search the dark/undiscovered tiles for some new pack members.

Niche may seem like a fun and easy game but the cute graphics are very decieving. Yet it's never to much of a challenge. It may throw constant stuff at you but the solutions are often easy to do, if somewhat anoying. Niche is fun cute and a great challenge to work your brain. I wouldn't ecommend it for a time of lay back and have fun, but if your mind wants a challenge throw Niche at it and have a good time. 26577486.review:
Edit: I played it before the little islands so I played it again to see if the changes mattered. I think with the smaller area it is easier to extend the life of your animals. However if you want to migrate, then you have to move all of the animals you want to keep around a certain tile and interact with that tile. I like that idea. Only the strongest make it to the next area. The only problem is making sure that whole new pack is well enough on food to make the journey. So you sacrifice a few of your gatherers to make sure the new pack will come out with enough food to start anew. The new "marking" is great though. Now you can change the colors of the animals' AP (R,G,B) so you can distinguish between them at a quick glance. Randoms still are garbage though. I know they're RNG but I ran into 3 in my recent play through. 2 were blind and all 3 were about 5 turns from death. I found them within 15 turns.

At first I didn't recommend the game and honestly I still think it needs work but I think that the developers love their game and it shows in even just one update. Keep it up guys.

I bought this game because it looked interesting and new. The only problem was that your animals just die off too quickly. Genetically altering your future brood to what you want is next to impossible because you end up just breeding to keep players on the field. The randoms you run into only make it worse for you because they are never worth it and so you use them to find more sources of food but in turn they eat your stash right to nothing. I suppose you could just have them not move and just eventually die off because they also are usually right next to death when you find them as well.

Maybe you can add something that tells you who the parents are of the kids? If you're going to make it to where incest can ruin your stats, then why not make it so you know what family that animal is in. Maybe even have a family tree with traits of the parents even?

Le jeu est plus complexe que le trailer nous laisse comprendre. C'est cute, c'est addictif et ça demande de la réflexion.

26366526.review:
Niche is a wonderful, fun and addicting game. Even as an early access game all the content is there to make it a fully functional and fun game. I can only see it getting better as the develops move forward with it.

Every different save file puts you in a different environment where you need to plan your moves carefully to make sure your creatures not only survive, but develop the best genes possible. It starts out simple enough but as you progress it starts to get more complicated as you need to plan who pairs up best to produce a baby with the best genes. Expanding your territory comes with risks as you can either find something beneficial..or something that can wipe out your pack completely if you aren't careful. 

I would highly recommend this game if you are looking for a fun and rewarding game, one that is both relaxing but also makes you think :)

26359048.review:
A series of videos highlighting this game showed up in my recommended feed on YouTube and I was intrigued. Before I knew it, I ended up watching two hours worth of videos of someone else playing the game. I actually started using Steam just for THIS game. I had to have it. I love that the creatures are cute and pretty variable despite the fairly small number of genes at the moment.

This game is challenging in different way than I am used to, it requires some logic and experimentation to survive. For example, in my most recent save file I had a surplus of food and pack members but was getting bored and running out of space. So I decided to use about four of my creatures to explore nearby territory and branch out into different zones. However, this proved to be chaos for my pack. I quickly depleted my food stores and carnivores wiped out half of my adults. The remaining creatures went back to the original territory to repopulate. They've survived so far but inbreeding is becoming an issue as we've not found any wild creatures for a while to increase our gene pool.

I've become very attached to my little family and am looking forward to watching this game expand!

26331726.review:
Niche is a Great game, not only is it fun and challenging it also can teach you.

Niche is "composed" of 2 aspects genetics and survival. The genetics part is what really brings the fun :) there are as of this review 73 different genes (Though some are similar) and 18 gene slots. Most genes (57) change the appearance of the creature and the non cosmetic ones give creatures various abilities to help thier survival. But not all genes are helpful some such as no paw, hemophilia and blind eyes hinder your creatures and now for the most fun part  breeding. Breeding is essentiall for survival but you must choose your pairs wisely because you don't want double immunity creatures running around.

Now for the survival, Each creature needs 1 food at the end of each day so you're going to need to balance the amount of creatures you have so you don't starve. This is where your genes come in Strength allows you to hunt prey and defend your self from carnivores, collecting allows you to gather berries, digging for roots, cracking for nuts and shells and fishing for well fish (All food when collected is the same). As i have already mentioned you need to defend your self from other creatures. Depending on which island you are on their will be differentt threats, on most islands their is the carnivore the "medium" predator, on jungle and mountain there is the apes and balance bear which are 'Hard" predators, but you don't just need to defend you self from predators, rouge males will breed from your females (not good) blue birds will steal unprotected children and dodomingos will steal nests.

26318772.review:
As of right now, this game is not fleshed out (expected) and is not worth the price they're asking for it. However, I have enjoyed it so far and am hoping that, with some support, they will continue working on this.

To date, it's not very complicated. Eat, breed, kill something, eat, breed, kill something, and so on. There's a certain amount of strategy involved to improve and expand upon your genetics, as well as finding a good place to set up "camp." But right now, you're looking at maybe 5 hours to unlock all of the genetic options and explore your map. While there is more than one map, the variety isn't enough to offer any real replay value.

Overall, a really neat concept and I look forward to seeing how it develops.

26207427.review:
well myfirst game;

-Started in th savanna/plains
-Adam and Eve bred produce baby
-Lots of wonderers with short lifespans. Oh look two babies! ¬_¬
-4 carnivores and the death of Adam and Eve later
-Well I've got 4 nests, 4 breeding females and some berries. I'm forced to grab cactus berries whenevera carnivoreome along. 
-How am I managing to keep the immunity genes alive? breeding the hell out of everyone!  I manage to keep hold of both = genes, the triangle, circle and + one. with 5 genes, I had a choice of pack mates.  I nevr saw any other gene and honstly, the way the first 4 carnivores tore through my pack at the start, I on't think I really had time to consider things.
-All I have is spitsnot and claws. 
-next thing I know... 6 nests and 30+ members.

Okay so I learn early on the secret was to focus less on keeping traits I wanted and more about breeding for the sake of immunity genes. There were times I took inbreeding risks for the sake of maintaing a circle or + sign one. I had female constantly in the nest breeding.  

So I also took some notes from nature and how animals behave.  I kept the young in the centre of the pack protected by the adults and slowly moved the access adults out.  By keepingthe young in the centre not only did I have a circle of protection to them, but I also had a breeding stock at hand near nests.  As one partner died I moved a baby with a gene the other partner didn't hve into breed. I never had less then 12 babies in the centre at all times.  I always took breeding from them and pushed out the unwanted members to keep the gene pool fresh.

As I said, the big weakness was genetics for survival... I lost the berry paw really fast, and the big nose. I had a rams hend but lost it within 1 generation.  The poison fangs, however, survived because of Eve and Adam's soul off spring survived.  Otherwise I had a army of spitsnouts.  I managed to load up a berry paw and bring it back into the mix later but tht was when I had 20 individuals. 

I know some advise making paths in the grass but I foun it stronger as a move to slowly expand the terroritory one bit at a time.  This meant the carnivores and bunnies had nowhere to hide and made sur the back areas of area arond nests was safely exposed. I also made sure no one in the outter areas of the pack was alone without at lest 2 back up pack members.

I do like the random nature of the breeding and exploring... Even my best plans had flaws.  I nearly lost a immunity gene.  But once you have 4 nests down and a decent amount of pack members and berries to pick, the game becomes easier even if you mess up.

Edit:
The island migration update changed a lot of things, but there are some conclusions I've come to. 

1- Eventually you'll come to an island where instead of the carnivores hunting you, you hunt them.  They produce 10 food and there are few bushes to raid and sometimes trees.  So you need to turn focus away from running and berry collecting and towards double claws and ram horms/antlers.
2-At this point, I realised you can only have x amount of females on nest, so taking a note out of Lions I sent the etra females off to scout.  Yes, horny males were a problem, but I wasn't breeding from the ones sent off. 
3-I surrounded each nest with a harem of males.  The males gave a genetic selection for the nest sitting female.  They doubled as shielding the females on nests from horny males. 
4-hunting females went out solo, they were often fresh out of the nest with ram or antlers and double claws. They scout slowly the island and found and killed carnivores while slowly unveiling the grasses.
5-expansion was slow, I could only breed when a carnivore was downed.  At this point the spawn rate was high on them so they were appearing almost every other turn.  Later on as the double claw and antlers became common, I was able to slowly push out, get to other nests, hunt down the carnivores more effectly and things sped up.  
6-The trick on slow epansionw as to never have more then one or two scouts, even if they were slow double claws, they could slowly cut way the map.  Patience was rewarding. 
7-Trees were often more valuable then bushes.  while I would sit one female gathering the acorns, bushes were just cut down while the girls were hunting. 
8-If your lucky, you may get a double bush near a nest.  Carnivore high spawn rates means even then a double berry paw is dangerous.  Your creature is vunerable.  It becomes a high risk, especially as often its not worth it unless it rains.
9-So about the females who are moved away from the nests.  Okay so there was always 4-6 females not breeding I could not do anything with.  Occasionally a horny male would come along and a baby would result.  This is a gamble.  I clustered them together to ATTRACT the males. Sometimes the males gave a hidden trait among their rubbish genetics, like a immunity gene.  I know some hate these guys, but often their a blessing in disguise.  Early on, when you move onto a new island sometimes things are cruel.  I traveled to island 3 with 8 young and strong individuals but their numbers fell.  I was lucky to find 3 nests within a few squares of each other.  But I ran out of food looking for food.  So I ended up with a shallow gene pool in immunity genes - until a horny male blessed one female with both toxic body AND a new immunity gene.  I had to breed out their crap genetics, but I think thats the idea.  
10- about 50% of the island unveiled leaves a lot of dark areas for carnivores to spawn.  cut that grass ASAP to get finding them easy to do.  Without grass they lack the element of surprise and can't ambush you.  By 100% of the map unveiled, they are exposed, weak and this makes them just sitting ducks even for slow double claw paws.  
11-you don't always have to have plenty of food to migrate if you've made the right breeding.  The first migration to island 3 I had 24 food.  The result was I bred rarely.  5 of my guys had to be sacrficed for the greater good of the pack.  They were the first scouts. Their efforts unveiled the areas that made carnivores easy to find.  Their deaths weren't in vein.  Sometimes, you have to choose between the death of a few pack members like this.  But neverless, it is possible to get migration through on less then 40 food and prosper.  

Basically, the game pushes you more and more to become less "hunter/gather" and more "hunter" it seems later on in the current migration update.  The most valuable traits right now are toxic body, poison fang, ram horns, antlers, double claw paws, Lean body (edit; sorryI left this one out).  Speed and gather paws are almost useless. You have to bait and wait for the right things to come to the nests, be it prey or mates.

26134489.review:
I love this game!
It's a little bit too expensive right now but I couldn't wait - however, I don't regret buying. I hope there's going to be more content! 

+ so cute!
+ simple but challenging enough
(+ the video was great :D You should make a tutorial for the game with that not-an-actual-professor guy) 

- needs much more content
- no family tree or genealogy (I wish I could see my progress, game would be more rewarding that way) 

I think the challenging part is getting enough food. But I haven't lost yet so I guess it's not too hard. 

If you are impatient like me - go ahead and buy it. Otherwise, wait until the price goes down.

ps. some of you say that there's no camera rotation possibility but yes there is - just press the right mouse button and drag! And I heard there actually is going to be the family tree, so I'll come back and write my review about it then.

Some tips: Think before breeding. If one animal has one blind gene and another doesn't have any - there's 75% possibility that their descendant doesn't have the blind gene and with mutations you can affect to that possibility. But if the both animals have one blind gene - the possibility is 50%. But even if the descendant isn't blind - it still can carry the blind gene. And this logic should stand for the another genes as well.

Don't chase rabbits - wait them to jump next to you and then attack. It's a good idea to keep one animal next to berry bush so you can collect food when ever you need it - and do not destroy the bushes because they won't grow back then. Killing the carnivores might be hard - but it's the best source of food.

26109700.review:
It's a simple game where you help a tribe of animals survive for as long as you can. You can also track the genetic traits of each animal and even choose up to two mutations that the tribe's offspring can have.
It has a steep learning curve where you must learn by trial-and-error, but when you figure it out it's rather easy to master. I would recommend this game for casual players who want to learn the basics of heredity and gene flow. In fact, I may even recommend this to a high school biology class!

I love this game! Even though not all of the features are available yet, its still crazy fun and cute. The game has simple rules, yet it can be challenging too (I still cant get a clan to keep the poison fang gene...) I would totally recommend to anyone who loves science and biology. Its both a relaxing game and yet one that requires a sharp eye and a knack for strategy,

Not only would I love to see new genes like other reviewers have mentioned, but I would also like to see more complexity in the genes we already have. Maybe we could have the small chance of getting a secret gene mutation if we combine two gene types (Example: claw paws+runner leg = Digging paws)

Another idea would be to have different levels of skills based on how much of a gene a creature has. For example, one berry paw gives you the ability to pick lots of berries off bushes, but TWO berry paws give you the ability to pick berries safely off cacti.

I do hate the fact that we can destroy our food source bushes. I've had to start over twice because of it. There are just too many dots to keep track of what you click sometimes, and I think it adds an element of unnecessary stress to the game play.

Please try Niche and give the developers your support, this game has a lot of future potential.

25983403.review:
[h1]A.A.A Geni di qualità cercasi[/h1]

[i]...

Al momento, Niche prevede un’unica modalità di gioco di stampo “endless”. Questa ci porrà a capo di un branco di animali primitivi con lo scopo di garantire loro la sopravvivenza. Cominceremo dunque con due soli esemplari (maschio e femmina, logicamente) entro un ambiente di gioco selvaggio, di modeste dimensioni, suddiviso in caselle esagonali e generato proceduralmente all’inizio della partita.

L’iter di gioco si presenta decisamente chiaro e intuitivo, e può a grandi linee essere suddiviso tra ricerca di cibo, esplorazione dell’habitat e attenta ponderazione dei movimenti, sopravvivenza della specie a livello numerico e, infine, selezione dei geni migliori mediante accoppiamenti accorti e lungimiranti.

...

[b]Concludendo...[/b]
Forte di un concept dal grande potenziale, l’offerta complessiva di Team Niche si presenta funzionale ma di certo non ricca. È una situazione pienamente comprensibile dato lo stadio di sviluppo poco più che embrionale: siamo soltano alla versione 0.0.7, e quasi certamente durante i prossimi mesi verranno rilasciati numerosissimi contenuti atti a rimpolpare il pacchetto. Tuttavia, per quanto riguarda Niche “hic et nunc”, il prezzo richiesto non può che essere considerato poco concorrenziale. Guardando al futuro possiamo ritenerci ottimisti, ma trattasi di previsioni che non possono in alcun modo essere scambiate per certezze. Quanto alla valutazione dell’early access, non abbiamo avuto modo di constatare alcuna problematica tecnica o bug. Anzi, dal punto di vista grafico e sonoro Niche è risultato piacevole e ben curato.
Discretamente soddisfatti, attendiamo fiduciosi.[/i]

Leggi l'anteprima completa su [url=www.cyberludus.com/2016/10/11/niche-a-genetics-survival-game-anteprima]Cyberludus[/url] o fai un salto sul nostro gruppo Steam CyberludusItalia.

Niche is a very intresting game with a very interesting concept. You play a psudeo-god who can control and help a speices survive by collecting,
food, fending off attacks and most importantly, breeding and evolving your speices of animal.
It makes you feel challenged but not frustrated. At some points you are making progress until you get a little cocky and the game punishes you for it, the mechanic of the enemy wolf stalking you amoungst the tall grass makes you paranoid... at least, for me it did.
The abilities and evolutions you can use are suprisingly handy and helped me
out in a pinch sometimes. The biomes are pretty cool. The music is nice and ambient. I have
yet to expierence any bugs, the movement and when the AI moves takes a little getting used to.
And the improvements that the devs have made are really noticable.

                                     I'd give it a solid 8/10

25797710.review:
Итак, в нашем распоряжении крошечная популяция из двух особей... лис, я думаю.  Они взрослые, разнополые и готовы к возрождению лисьей популяции в этом районе. А ещё, тут же, тотальная нехватка еды, слишком шустрая дичь, которую можно поймать только хитростью или выжиданием и более крупные хищники, которым, почему-то, очень нравится лисье мясо. Задача популяции - выжить. И, уже от этой основной задачи и пляшет весь геймплей. В результате вы, постоянно работая лисьей свахой и нянькой, носитесь по всей карте в поисках сьедобных растений и крупных хищников, ибо с них мяса падает в разы больше. А ещё сидите и мучительно раздумываете на какой бы кривой козе подьехать к популяции, что бы рецессивный ген смог пробиться сквозь крепкие ряды доминантных. А потом, снова носитесь по карте, только уже в поисках "свежей крови" в вашу популяцию. И снова разводите, стараясь рецессивный ген переделать в доминантный. Потом вы находите ещё пару гнёзд, в которых возможно размножение и ведёте уже не одну, а несколько совершенно разных популяций, ориентированных на разные задачи - сбор еды, сражение с хищниками и... бег по карте. А потом приходит болезнь и уничтожает всю вашу популяцию, оставляя двух однополых её представителей и ты, в очередной раз проклиная рандом, снова бежишь по карте, разыскивая хоть какую-нибудь, даже самую завалящую девочку, которую можно подложить под своих пацанов.

Плюсы:
+ Необычный геймплей, завязанный на не самой популярной концепции разведения. Это реально круто, особенно для меня, как для человечка, глубоко изучавшего генетику в своё время.
+ Не такой уж поверхностный рандом на доминантные или рецессивные гены. Ещё там можно увеличить шанс непредусмотренных мутаций определённой направленности, кстати.
+ Пошаговость. У тебя есть время среагировать на угрозу и, к примеру, убрать с дороги хищника детёнышей и побыстренькому пригнать армию мускулистых солдат.
+ Графика. Очень приятная стилизация, радующая глаз.
+ Вариативность. Большой набор различных деталей существ, каждая из которых даёт свои плюсы и минусы. По факту, меняющихся критериев не так уж много, но сам факт их сочетаемости не может не радовать.
+ Милые лисы. Ну, это тоже плюс, я думаю.

А теперь о минусах:
- Скука. Да, первое время геймлей в виде бега по карте вызывает определённый интерес, но, к сожалению, в долгосрочной перспективе, игре нечего вам предложить. Вы просто из раза в раз продолжаете делать одно и то же, в тайне надеясь на что-то новое. Но нового не происходит и вы начинаете скучать.
- Очень однообразные рандомные карты. Такого разнообразия биомов и просто необычных обьектов, показанных на скринах, в самой игре просто не существует (ну, по крайней мере, не с такой густотой. Биомов, кстати, несмотря на то, что я, ради интереса, генерировала с десяток карт, мне не попалось ни разу)
- Музыка. Нет, возможно, именно такая музыка и нужна подобным играм - лёгкая и фоновая. Вот только, я даже не помню не то что мотив, а была ли она вообще в игре... Наверное была. То есть, мне так кажется... наверное.
- Отсутсвие разнообразных режимов. То есть, выживание на единой сложности, это всё что у вас есть. Ни сделать сложнее/легче, не отключить необходимость в еде, что бы просто поиграться с генетикой, без вечного забега по карте, нельзя. Как я уже сказала, вы просто бегаете по карте и строгаете детёнышей. Всё. Без вариантов.
- Отсутствие мультиплеера. Да-да, я знаю, что это вовсе не обязательное условиях в играх и ставить подобное в минус инди-игре как минимум бестактно, но... Мультиплеер мог бы хотя бы частично развеять скуку и позволить поупарываться вдвоём, выводя странных созданий или, к примеру, разводя две соперничающие популяции, что бы в один момент сразиться за превосходство на карте! В общем, это такой опциональный минус, если в игру добавлят больше разнообразного контента, то и мультиплеер не понадобиться.
Я отдаю себе отчёт, что это игра с ранним доступом и смею надеяться, что в будущем создатели игры уделят, наконец, внимание не только генетике, но и разнообразию, которое не дало бы заскучать в процессе выведения очередной пачки потомства.
Тем, кто не интересуется разведением животных и выведением более благополучного потомства, на мой взгляд, на данный момент делать в игре нечего и покупать ее не стоит. А мне она понравилась.

25736476.review:
Thank you, Team Niche, for providing me with a free copy of your game!

I am loving this game!  The graphics are gorgeous and the game runs smoothly for me.  This is a game about expanding your territory, finding food to keep your tribe fed, and protecting your tribe from carnivores.  Rustling grass might be a bunny that you so desperately need for food, or it could be a carnivore who wants YOU for food.  Take him down and get a nice amount of food for your tribe.  You also need to keep an eye on your creatures dominant and recessive genes when breeding.  If you don't, your creatures could be born with genes that cause them to get sick easier, be born blind, or have other weaknesses.  Will you breed a tribe of hunters? Will you breed a tribe of berry gatheres?  Maybe explorers?  Or maybe a tribe full of all types!  It's up to you!  

What I do feel is needed in the game is some sort of tutorial to get you started, especially with understanding the genes and how they figure into breeding.  I was a bit lost at first, and although I did eventually start figuring things out, a tutorial would have definitley been welcome.  

That said, the game is still in early access.  There are a lot more genes planned and what sounds like more biomes to explore, and I am really looking forward to seeing and playing with those!  Overall, this is a fun, relaxing game that does require some strategy to grow your tribe by breeding for strong, healthy members, expanding your territory, and protecting your tribe from carnivores all while trying to gather enough food to not starve!  This game can be difficult to put down.  I know I need to stop playing, but I always want to play through just one more day!

When I was in high school, my biology class eventually hit the unit on genetics. The concept was really interesting to me, so I have a soft spot for games that deal with breeding and genetics.

In this game you have two creatures to start. Your goal is to get a healthy population going. Of course, this might be a little difficult because you not only need to explore your territory but you need to gather food in which  to help your population thrive. You'll need to keep a varied gene pool, or else the liklihood of disease wiping out your population runs high. Soe people are calling this a rogue-like game. I'm in disagreement with this as it's not in a dungeon, but it is turn-based.

Still in it's development phase, the game shows a lot of promise, ut this game might not be for you if you're into action and adventure. If you like slower, more cerebral games, this might appeal more towards you.

25622205.review:
I was lucky to be involved during the alpha phase of this game, so my actual playtime (through the many massive iterations) is quite a bit higher than the time logged on steam.

Niche is a very novel blend of classic rogue-lite survival (think Don't Starve) with clever turn-based management and - true to its title - genetics mixed in. It certainly takes a while to get the hang of it, and to remember keeping track of all the important values - but it's just a really satisfying feeling when you're able to survive anything (procedural) mother nature throws at you.

The game evolved a lot during its alpha phase - I've seen it transition from a more board-game inspired title (with a very limited, linear world + progression) over to the much more free-form version that is playable today. The developers really closely interacted with the alpha testers during that phase, a lot of feedback got taken to heart and I feel that the community so far really had a big impact on shaping the game as it is now. Being an early access title, I think that's a very vital part of the equation, and I'm really looking forward to what's yet to come.

Dieses Spiel macht einfach unheimlich Spaß. 

https://youtu.be/x4cxewo5YLk

Ich hatte das Spiel bereits bei Greenlight gesehen und wollte es umbedingt haben. Nun Punktlich zum releas erhielt ich vom Publisher sogar ein Key zum Testen und Let´s Playen ;) Danke nochmal Team Niche

Worum geht es?
Niche ist ein Rundenbasierendes Strategie Survival Spiel. 
Jedes Spiel beginnt mit dem selben Paar Adam und Eve auf einer Random generierten Insel. 

Nun muss man sich sein eigenes Rudel aufbauen. Dazu kann man mit Adam und Eve  Nachkommen zeugem. Beim erkunden der Insel findet man auch weitere Tiere für das Rudel, die den Genpool mit frischen Genen und neuen Eigenschaften auffrischen.  Aber auch Feinde sind im hohem Gras zu finden, gegen die sich das Rudel vertreidigen muss. 

Dadurch, dass kein Spiel gleich ist, durch die zufälligen Gefährten und durch die verschiedenen Paarungen und damit unterschiedlichen Eigenschaften der Tiere, hat das Spiel einen hohen Wiederspielwert. 

Also eine klare Empfehlung. Wer gern möchte kann sich das Spiel auch gern bei mir auf dem Kanal anschauen um zu sehen ob es einem Spaß machen würde!

25557403.review:
Niche is a unique strategy game where the goal is to breed your animals & make your tribe stronger through genetic mutation. This game feels like a turn based style with charming graphics & adds a good concept, Genetics! Something we all should of learned in biology class.
You start next to a bush, a nest & 2 animals. The interface is easy. Click on the animal. It tells you what its name is, its gender, its abilities & its genes. These genes will help you when breeding. If you'd want to name them, you can't! Some of the names I've come across are dumb. VanVanVan is one of them. The white line that's above your animals name is their LIFEBAR. If your animal gets sick, gets attacked, you starve it or your animal eats berries from a thorn bush, you'll shorten your animals life & the damage shows up as a red bar. 
The game gives you an unfinished tutorial  that doesn't include the controls. Took me 5 hours to discover how to turn the camera Q & E. Zoom is R & F. On the bottom right side of your screen you'll see a DNA icon. This was never explained but i call it PLAYING GOD. You get a chance to add 2 genes to your animals & put them on the 10% & 30%. If you mix & match some genes, a green color will appear saying you can unlock a new gene. Eventually one of your offspring will make a new gene. 
The animals have action pendants on their chests. You can preform 3 actions per day for each. Each stage of life is different. Babies only have 1 action, teens have 2 & adults have 3. There are 4 different actions you can preform. Gathering, Moving, Making Love & Attacking. You need to spend FOOD POINTS for each action. These are located at the bottom right of your screen with a apple icon. You will also find new animals to breed within the bushes that will generate in Niche so your tribe can avoid having incest.  For the actions, you can attack a carnivore to shorten its life & try to kill it for its meat before it kills you, gather the meat afterwords from your kill (you can kill bunnies too), you can gather berries, you can attack the bush for more berries but the bush never regenerates, you can make love & move your animal. The next day button is located on the bottom right side. 
In the Ability section of each animal, there will be different abilities. The ones to note are Speed, Strength & Collecting. The number next to the ability will determine how much you can move, how much attack power you'll do & how much food you can collect. Not every animal will have speed, strength or collecting. If your animal only has collecting & not strength, that means it can only collect berries. It can't attack. Attackers can't gather either. Some of your animals will be able to have both of these abilities.
GENES! Please take the time to look at each one of your animals genes. I found out if your animal has white eyes, they're blind & will not be able to go out & explore on their own. If there are no other animals around them, the spaces will begin to go dark the further out your blind animal goes, preventing it from traveling to spaces you've previously discovered or want to discover. 
Overall this game is great to play & they'll be adding new features like a water feature where you can probably swim in the future to different islands but developers please take notes. If you can't have a decent tutorial explaining the gameplay, the controls, how genes work, then your players will find this game too difficult to understand & stop without seeing its full potential. So I Recommend it in its early stages because i can see this game going far. If you want to support it, buy it.

Key was provided to me by the developer.

Niche - a genetics survival game gives you the task of survival through the exploitation of Genetics. A very cool concept. You start with 2 creatures with a series of special traits between them and you begin creating offspring. You need to gather food to allow you to explore the map, find food, find more creatures to potentially breed desired traits with and also protect yourself from predators. Each creature has a limited life span effected by time, illness and damage. Better breeding by avoiding incest and pairing good traits will limit your chances of breeding sickly or likely to become ill offspring.
Its a game of incredibly careful balance, you have to monitor the size of your group as food is shared but also keep numbers high enough to you don't run out of males or females with desired traits to ensure your survival. 
It's a cool game with a great concept. It is very early but the base work of this game shows a very great idea I think. Defiantly worth keeping your eye on if it interests you.

25524889.review:
EDIT 22-9-2016

Since I seem not to quite get my point across and after some discussion in the comments on this thing I figured I should rephrase this and add some things that were requested of me including my own thought on the game. Perhaps I've been to clinical about this.

TL;DR of this review:
- If you want to support a game with a lot of potential, I do reconmend this game. Even if at the moment of this review it is rather barebones
- As stated in on the early acess dropdown of the shop page, it is in alpha and you have done about everything you can after playing for about 5 hours. So I don't reconmend it at this price for people looking for a more in depth experiene at this moment. That would definitely not be worth the rather expensive price tag.

-----------------------------------

First off, I'd like to state that I was really excited for this game. I got it as soon as I could buy it and I've played for a little more then 2 hours.

GAMEPLAY

In a nutshell this game gives you two creatures to start with. Adam and Eve. These creatures are the basis of your pack of creatures. It's up to you to maintain the population, make sure you don't breed in genetical flaws that hinder your creatures (usualy caused by inbreeding) and make sure your creatures don't starve in the process.

The mechanics are simple. Adult creatures get 3 actions every day. These actions require food points. In order to act, you need food, in order to find food, you need to explore. Things like movement, attacking, harvesting, exploring and mating all take up an action. its up to the player to balance this and not to have their population starve.

MY 5 CENTS

I enjoy this game and I think it has a lot of potential for growth as more mechanics get added to it. While I've done everything that is to be done in about 3 to 5 hours of gameplay it has been a fun experience. Though I will probably wait untill the next update to play more of it. At this point it starts to feel a little same-ish and repetative, but thats to be expected with the limitted amount of features.

There's currently some issues with starting in the savanah area as most berry bushes have thorns making it rather hard to gather enough food to do much. But I've found it can be somewhat mittigated by finding prey warrens to harvest.

Also my pets freak out over the sounds and get all excited, thats really entertaining too.

RECOMMENDATIONS

If you want to support the developer then feel free to buy the game at full price. It certainly has potential. 

Right now the game feels a little bare bones and at its current price I really can't reconmend it to players who are looking for a more full experience. Maybe the finished product will be worth it in the end, but as it stands it almost feels like I'm playing the demo to a larger game.

25519816.review:
Niche has a huge amount of potential.  Guide your pack of endearing animals through an unexplored world, search for food, and defend yourself against predators.  Gathering enough food for your pack is fairly difficult, depending on how lucky you are with the randomly generated map.  You'll have to find a balance between having enough babies to secure the bloodline and saving food so that the pack won't starve.  Camouflage is absent in the current version, making hunting difficult.  You'll also want to selectively breed your most genetically advantageous pairs- developing a tribe with no front paws is entirely possible, and a really bad idea.

The genetics system is not yet fleshed out, but the idea of unlocking new mutations over generations is already addicting, and will become more so with expanded content.  Arguably, the price is a little steep for what's currently there, but I'm impressed enough to be confident in the investment.

25518780.review:
Niche,
a survival, management, strategy game with relaxing gameplay.
I kind of enjoy my 70 minutes of gameplay in this game and would continue to play again later.

You have to build a colony of animal and survive as long as you can. In order to do that you will have to find foods, breed your colony, protect your pack from carnivors, explore the island. While the gameplay looks simple, however there is more indepth gameplay you will eventually learn by yourself as you are playing, and it is not that hard to learn the game.

If you are new to the game, look at the right bottom and click the "?" mark to have a quick start.

-THE PACK-
With 2 starter of animal (Adam and Eve), you should get them married and get a new pup to expand the pack. When expanding the pack you could later on find new species which gives better features to you (more eye sight, more attack power, more movement, more food gathering ability, etc). By finding these animals with new genes you could get better features for each animal in which will help further in your gameplay.

-THE FOOD-
For every action of each animal (move, gather food, attack), you will need one food. If you make action without having food you will deplete your health (in which will shorten your animal lifespan). You can collect foods by: finding bushes (1 to 6 berries), killing rabbits (2 foods), or killing carnivores (10 foods). Beware that some bushes has torn and would hurt your animal if you collect it. As foods are scarce, sometimes you will need to move around to find new bushes. Rain will refill all bushes again.

-AGE-
The animals have 4 stage. Newborn (no action), kid (1 actions), teens (2 actions), adult (3 actions). I am not sure how many nights for each animal to reach adult stage. However once you reach adult stage, each animal would get old and died eventually once the age meter has been full. Every time you hurt your animal, you will shorten the lifespan. Finding animals in the wild would have random stage of age, which sometimes they are already too old and will die in a couple nights.

-EXPLORE-
You will eventually have to explore the island. By exploring you could find new food source, new nest, new animals, rabbit holes, rabbit, somekind of stone (i dunno what the stone for. prob just blocking the way), and eventually a carnivores. When exploring, keep your eyes on the moving grasses. If there is moving grass, you could find new pack, rabbit (foods), and carnivore (uh oh, nightmare).

-MOVEMENT-
Animals with higher movement points could move further. Be aware animals with low eye sight would be trouble some to move around by itself (you have to clear the path before moving). It is best to stay with animals with lower eye sight to help them moving around. Moving in pack would also help for faster movement, you could create some kind of movement chain for further movement. Clearing the path will help movement for your animals.

-SURVIVING-
Survival is not easy. Sometimes it is better to sacrifice some animals in order to survive the whole pack from danger. I sometimes leave 1 animal near food resource while moving the others. Sometimes when carnivore come I would use 1 animal for lure and run away. For thorny bushes, I use the old animals to collect them. Be aware that some animals could get sick, make sure to seperate them from pack or it will spread.

-LAST WORDS-
As i mentioned above, i really enjoy the game. Survival is hard. Yes, sometimes you will find it very hard to find food source. I even sacrifices 9 out of 10 animals to find another food source, in the end with this 1 last animal I could find another new pack and food sources.

Should you buy this game?
If you like to play survival game, with management style, yes you should buy it. It is fun. It is challenging. Is it hard? Depends, but the hardship what makes the game fun. In the end it is up to you how will you make your pack survive.

25518636.review:
Niche is a seemingly simple game; you start with two animals and you breed them together in order to survive. As you progress through the game and explore different areas, you pick up other animals with different traits that you can breed into your family in order to increase their chances of survival. However, the game is way more complex than it comes off; you can mutate genes into your family, and you can choose to focus on either berry collection, or combat, each with their own strengths and weaknesses. 

Berry bushes (and cacti) contain berries that your tribe will eat, and each time you perform an action, you eat one unit of food. Occassionally rabbits will pop out (don't even bother chasing them, wait for them to come to you), and you can kill those for food. Rustling bushes will alert you to either a rabbit, another animal to add to your tribe, or a carnivore, which basically looks like some terrifying were-bear (let me tell you, when these things pop out of the bushes and scare the sh** outta you, you're gonna hate them too). 

Overall, I like the game. It's addictive, and it's challenging without being stressful. I have yet to discover a way to rename my animals, which would really help in distinguishing who is from what family to avoid inbreeding (which creates sickness). I think a better and more obvious tutorial would certainly benefit the game as well. All in all though, I do reccommend it, and it's a lot of fun.

25518529.review: This is a very interesting and unique take on a survival and strategy. You control a pack of animals and your aim of the game is to survive. No advancing to tribal stage or any direct form of civilization. Just you, your creatures, and all the elements that mother nature has to offer. It's a little hard at first, I had to start a new game a couple of times to spawn at a good location. Your creatures will breed, change, grow, die, and repeat. They only have 3 actions that they can perform on a single day. Each action cost 1 food, so food management is key in this game. You can alter your creatures genes in two ways that I've found. Either by breeding two different creatures with desired genes together (be careful of incest though), or by pulling up a menu of genes that have at this moment in time, two slots. One slot has a 30% chance of occuring in ofspring, and the other has a 10% chance. It's still missing some feature that will be added later on. Such as jungle, swamp, and water genes, as well as ancient genes and the ability to breed hybrids. This game despite being an early access is pretty solid and plays very well, and I'm very eager to see where they take it!

25514179.review:
Note: I've been playing for longer than Steam says due to even earlier-access copies from Kickstarter.

Niche is an interesting hex-based strategy game where you control a race of adorable creatures in their fight for survival. What's special is that the game features a genetics system that allows the group to have varied skillsets and natural talents, as well as natural defects if you aren't careful or inbreed them. At the moment, the game isn't too horribly difficult so long as you keep one male and one female alive, but it's still quite fun and going on a mission to uncover the entire island is a fun challenge that I've done quite a few times now. The game definitely has some great potential as it goes through it's early access stages, and with it's kickstarter being successful I can't wait to see what comes of it. :D

25513106.review:
This is my first time reviewing a game and due to my love of genetics I may be a little biased so I recommend watching lets plays or even trying out the early version demo they provide to see if it is the game for you. I Also have 15 or more additonal hours of playtime from demos and kicstarter betas. With that said I shall now say I defitely recomend the game and encourage those intersted in it to get it to help the devlopment team. This game has tons of potential and the dev team defitely is attentive to the community and encourages us to provide some ideas to further with its devlopment. The base work which we get to play now is defitely playable and entertaining there is still some UI problems but I am sure that will be addressed sooner or latter. Then the list of things to come is defitely exciting. The game may seem hard at first and seem impossible to get your group to survive but once you get the hang of it soon you can start selective breeding and trying to mutate genes so you can get desired looks and attributes. With selective breeding after getting the few you want you can choose new ones to mutate in another group this way you can make different groups that specialize at berry picking, fighting or hunting, and exploring great distances to expand your visible territory. As it develops I be sure to update this review with more info.

The creatures have four stages of life infant (1 day without parent sitting in nest), kid (3 days), teen (5 days), and adult (20 something days) If they get hurt while still newborns they die instantly otherwise they get one day taken off life span for everytime they get hurt. Right now there is no way to heal the damage but a couple of future genes healing spit and healing purr may be able to remove some red so they can last a little longer if they were hurt. Things that can hurt is moving or performing any action unless it is gathering food without any food availble in your storage. Picking berries off a cactus no gene exist yet that protects you from the thorns nor can you even get strong enough yet to cut it down. Then getting attack by a carnivore can also cause damage although you can breed for fighters that can basically one shot the carnivores so eventually they are no longer a threat. When it comes to food you can get berries from bushes which repleshies once a day if there is no drought going on and fully restorses when it first rains after it has not been raining. The bushes have 4 - 6 berries each and depending on your creatures paw traits they can collect either none to up to 4 berries per action. Carnivors that you kill then when you gther their meat don't need berry collecting paws to gather meat will give you 10 food while rabbits give you 3 food. Fishing and moles will be options in the near future as additonal sources of food. Other things that are incoming are aquatic genes which will let you travel to little islands and fish, able to make sterile hybrids with the carnivores, and a family tree as well as additonal things to look forward to.

For additional information this is a good place to look and reading updates there is also helpful
https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/80250451/niche-a-genetics-survival-game/description
